Good morning. - Morning. 53 00:02:29,895 --> 00:02:32,921 It sounded like you were having pretty radical sex last night, 54 00:02:32,998 --> 00:02:34,431 all night long. 55 00:02:34,500 --> 00:02:35,592 Who was the guy? 56 00:02:35,668 --> 00:02:36,726 No one you know. 57 00:02:36,802 --> 00:02:38,360 ![pic](Chuckling) 58 00:02:38,437 --> 00:02:39,802 We're late. Let's go. 59 00:02:39,872 --> 00:02:41,737 ![pic](Meredith) If life's so hard already, 60 00:02:41,807 --> 00:02:44,537 why do we bring more trouble down on ourselves? 61 00:02:44,610 --> 00:02:47,443 What's up with the need to hit the self-destruct button? 62 00:02:47,513 --> 00:02:50,107 Yikes, wouldn't want to meet you in a dark alley. 63 00:02:50,182 --> 00:02:51,547 Right back at you. 64 00:02:51,617 --> 00:02:52,743 ![pic](Izzie) A run? You run? 65 00:02:52,818 --> 00:02:54,786 Every day, babe, every day. 66 00:02:54,854 --> 00:02:56,788 Not suffering enough? 67 00:02:56,856 --> 00:02:58,983 What doesn't kill you, makes you stronger. 68 00:02:59,058 --> 00:03:00,821 Don't go acting all indefatigable. 69 00:03:00,893 --> 00:03:02,690 You're dragging like the rest of us. 70 00:03:02,761 --> 00:03:05,355 Oh, what is that, professional weakness, Dr. Yang? 71 00:03:05,431 --> 00:03:07,729 - It's called the flu. - Yeah. 72 00:03:07,800 --> 00:03:11,566 I need a major rush to make it through this day. 73 00:03:11,637 --> 00:03:13,036 I need a kick-ass surgery. 74 00:03:13,105 --> 00:03:15,005 Ooh, you a bad boy last night, George? 75 00:03:15,074 --> 00:03:16,803 That would be Meredith. 76 00:03:16,876 --> 00:03:19,344 You a bad boy, Meredith? 77 00:03:19,411 --> 00:03:20,742 Do tell. 78 00:03:20,813 --> 00:03:22,212 Nothing to tell. 79 00:03:22,281 --> 00:03:24,715 That says it all, huh? 80 00:03:24,783 --> 00:03:26,614 Sorry, I have a sex life. 81 00:03:26,685 --> 00:03:29,017 Don't apologize. Embrace it. 82 00:03:29,088 --> 00:03:30,578 Share it. 83 00:03:30,656 --> 00:03:32,521 Count me in. 84 00:03:32,591 --> 00:03:35,389 Next time, just let me know if I need to go to a hotel 85 00:03:35,461 --> 00:03:37,122 so I can get some sleep. 86 00:03:37,196 --> 00:03:38,754 [Woman over PA] IV nurse, ICU. 87 00:03:38,831 --> 00:03:40,298 Am I missing something? 88 00:03:40,366 --> 00:03:42,197 You were just a little loud. 89 00:03:44,837 --> 00:03:48,238 Do they know it's McDreamy keeping them up all night? 90 00:03:48,307 --> 00:03:49,638 I hope not. 91 00:03:49,708 --> 00:03:51,300 I already have Bailey riding me. 92 00:03:51,377 --> 00:03:55,040 I don't need my roommates thinking I'm getting special treatment. 93 00:03:55,114 --> 00:03:57,344 ![pic](Yawning) 94 00:03:57,416 --> 00:04:02,285 O'Malley, Yang, Karev, go on to clinic. 95 00:04:02,354 --> 00:04:05,084 O'Malley, patients are waiting. 96 00:04:05,157 --> 00:04:06,522 You two come with me. 97 00:04:06,592 --> 00:04:08,890 ![pic](Bailey) Izzie, you're hanging with me today. 98 00:04:08,961 --> 00:04:10,428 Good morning, Dr. Shepherd. 99 00:04:10,496 --> 00:04:11,986 Dr. Bailey. 100 00:04:15,200 --> 00:04:17,464 Late night, Grey? 101 00:04:17,536 --> 00:04:19,697 No, caffeine just hasn't kicked in yet. 102 00:04:19,772 --> 00:04:23,230 If you're at all religious, you want to start praying it kicks in soon. 103 00:04:23,309 --> 00:04:24,742 There's a consult in the pit. 104 00:04:24,810 --> 00:04:26,937 Girl with a fever and abdominal pain. 105 00:04:27,012 --> 00:04:30,004 After that, Nicholas in 3311 needs his meds. 106 00:04:30,082 --> 00:04:32,880 Mr. Moeller's IV fell out, and he's a hard stick. 107 00:04:32,952 --> 00:04:37,548 Postops in 1337, 3342, 3363 and 2381. 108 00:04:37,623 --> 00:04:40,251 Three-eighty-one. 109 00:04:40,326 --> 00:04:43,887 Thirty-three-forty-two, 3363 110 00:04:43,963 --> 00:04:47,228 and 23... 111 00:04:47,299 --> 00:04:49,699 Why are you still standing in front of me? 112 00:04:51,370 --> 00:04:53,304 You look more like me than you right now. 113 00:04:53,372 --> 00:04:54,896 - What's the matter? - Nothing. 114 00:04:54,974 --> 00:04:56,771 ![pic](Woman) Help! I need immediate help. 115 00:04:56,842 --> 00:04:58,139 What's the problem? 116 00:04:58,210 --> 00:05:00,610 My damn boyfriend swallowed my keys. 117 00:05:00,679 --> 00:05:03,978 ![pic](Wheezing) I didn't want her to leave. 118 00:05:04,049 --> 00:05:06,279 Locate the lady's keys. 119 00:05:06,352 --> 00:05:10,152 I think she got some bug on her trip to Mexico with her friends. 120 00:05:10,222 --> 00:05:12,452 I told her not to go to a Third-World country, 121 00:05:12,524 --> 00:05:14,219 but does she ever listen? 122 00:05:14,293 --> 00:05:17,126 ![pic](Man) She's been weak ever since, and she's lost weight. 123 00:05:17,196 --> 00:05:18,458 Barely. 124 00:05:18,530 --> 00:05:21,761 And this morning, she passed out in the shower. 125 00:05:21,834 --> 00:05:23,301 When was the trip? 126 00:05:23,369 --> 00:05:24,859 A couple weeks ago. 127 00:05:24,937 --> 00:05:27,770 I'm really fine. I just have a fever. 128 00:05:28,707 --> 00:05:31,540 OK, well, will you lie back for an exam for me? 129 00:05:31,610 --> 00:05:34,602 No, please, I don't need an exam. 130 00:05:34,680 --> 00:05:37,877 Just give me some antibiotics and send me home. 131 00:05:37,950 --> 00:05:39,679 Well, maybe it is just a fever, 132 00:05:39,752 --> 00:05:41,481 but they called down for a surgeon, 133 00:05:41,553 --> 00:05:44,283 so I have to give the OK to let you go. 134 00:05:44,356 --> 00:05:46,756 So just let me do the exam. 135 00:05:49,528 --> 00:05:51,052 Do the exam. 136 00:05:51,130 --> 00:05:53,291 No. 137 00:05:53,365 --> 00:05:55,993 ![pic](Sighing) This is crazy. I'm fine. 138 00:05:56,068 --> 00:05:59,970 For God's sake, Claire, I don't want to spend my entire day here. 139 00:06:01,140 --> 00:06:02,767 You know, actually, Mrs. Rice, 140 00:06:02,841 --> 00:06:06,277 this might be easier if we had some privacy. 141 00:06:06,945 --> 00:06:09,277 So would you two mind leaving the room? 142 00:06:09,348 --> 00:06:11,043 [Mr. Rice] That's fine. 143 00:06:14,820 --> 00:06:17,653 Digby. Digby Owens. I have an appointment. 144 00:06:20,092 --> 00:06:23,027 Excuse me, sir, uh, you're bleeding. You mind if I... 145 00:06:23,095 --> 00:06:25,256 Sure, sure. Have a look. 146 00:06:26,231 --> 00:06:27,755 - That's a gunshot. - Yeah. 147 00:06:27,833 --> 00:06:31,200 We got a gunshot wound. We got to get him down to the pit. 148 00:06:31,270 --> 00:06:32,328 Sit, Mr... 149 00:06:32,404 --> 00:06:33,837 Uh... Digby. 150 00:06:33,906 --> 00:06:35,897 All right, but it isn't an emergency. 151 00:06:35,974 --> 00:06:38,033 - I scheduled it. - What, the gunshot? 152 00:06:38,110 --> 00:06:39,634 Yeah. My buddy shot me. 153 00:06:39,712 --> 00:06:41,509 - Buddy? - Yeah, just as a favor. 154 00:06:41,580 --> 00:06:43,070 - On purpose? - Hell, yeah. 155 00:06:43,148 --> 00:06:45,275 He wasn't trying to hurt me, but you know... 156 00:06:45,350 --> 00:06:47,944 - But why? - I like the scars. 157 00:06:50,456 --> 00:06:52,856 [- Psapp: Nobody Knows] 158 00:07:17,649 --> 00:07:19,617 Look, everyone in town has tats, 159 00:07:19,685 --> 00:07:21,653 but my art is about commitment. 160 00:07:21,720 --> 00:07:23,517 So, this your art, huh? 161 00:07:23,589 --> 00:07:25,079 ![pic](Digby) Damn straight. 162 00:07:25,157 --> 00:07:27,785 Damn stupid. The bullet went all the way through. 163 00:07:27,860 --> 00:07:29,350 Bounced off my ribs. 164 00:07:29,428 --> 00:07:31,726 I have another one still in my shoulder. 165 00:07:31,797 --> 00:07:33,765 Nice, huh? 166 00:07:34,366 --> 00:07:36,266 You could hang it in the Louvre. 167 00:07:36,335 --> 00:07:37,393 I have an ethos. 168 00:07:37,469 --> 00:07:39,403 Why do anything unless you're willing 169 00:07:39,471 --> 00:07:41,701 to go one step further than anybody else? 170 00:07:41,774 --> 00:07:43,901 What doesn't kill you makes you stronger. 171 00:07:43,976 --> 00:07:47,173 Exactly. And pain is the great divide. 172 00:07:47,246 --> 00:07:50,147 My coach used to say, it's all about how we process pain. 173 00:07:50,215 --> 00:07:51,239 Football? 174 00:07:51,316 --> 00:07:52,943 Wrestling, Iowa State. 175 00:07:53,018 --> 00:07:54,815 Iowa, 141. 176 00:07:54,887 --> 00:07:55,979 One-fifty-seven. 177 00:07:56,054 --> 00:07:57,988 You got to be more than 180 now. 178 00:07:58,056 --> 00:08:00,320 I'd like to see you get back under 145. 179 00:08:00,392 --> 00:08:02,917 Excuse me, but thinking of you men in tights 180 00:08:02,995 --> 00:08:06,192 makes me want to... puke. 181 00:08:06,265 --> 00:08:08,699 There's a flu going around the hospital. 182 00:08:08,767 --> 00:08:10,257 Somewhat ironic. 183 00:08:12,805 --> 00:08:14,466 ![pic](Claire) Ow. 184 00:08:15,641 --> 00:08:17,802 Don't push so hard. 185 00:08:19,278 --> 00:08:22,679 Can you lift your shirt so I can examine your stomach? 186 00:08:44,403 --> 00:08:46,564 Where did you get these? 187 00:08:50,976 --> 00:08:52,568 Claire... 188 00:08:52,644 --> 00:08:54,908 you've had surgery recently. 189 00:08:54,980 --> 00:08:56,572 These scars are still pink. 190 00:08:56,648 --> 00:08:58,843 Don't tell my parents. 191 00:08:59,785 --> 00:09:02,549 You did this in Mexico so your parents wouldn't know? 192 00:09:04,756 --> 00:09:06,485 What did you have done? 193 00:09:12,531 --> 00:09:13,657 ![pic](George) Ahh. 194 00:09:13,732 --> 00:09:16,030 And you noticed her foot twitching? 195 00:09:16,101 --> 00:09:17,932 - Come on, Jamie. - My foot. 196 00:09:18,003 --> 00:09:19,800 Oh, yeah. About three months ago? 197 00:09:19,872 --> 00:09:21,339 Just a little. 198 00:09:21,406 --> 00:09:24,034 We took her to County Hospital, and she got the CT scan, 199 00:09:24,109 --> 00:09:25,736 which showed her... 200 00:09:25,811 --> 00:09:28,041 Brain abnormality. Here, you can put it... 201 00:09:28,113 --> 00:09:30,707 - And the twitching has gotten worse? - A lot worse. 202 00:09:30,782 --> 00:09:34,513 They don't have the proper equipment back home to figure out what's wrong. 203 00:09:35,153 --> 00:09:37,587 - You did a... you did a good thing. - Show Mommy. 204 00:09:37,656 --> 00:09:40,523 - Yes, your mommy. - Show Mommy and Daddy. 205 00:09:40,592 --> 00:09:42,924 You did a good thing by coming all this way, 206 00:09:42,995 --> 00:09:44,394 Mr. And Mrs. Hayes. 207 00:09:44,463 --> 00:09:46,226 You sit tight, Jamie, OK? 208 00:09:46,298 --> 00:09:48,323 I'm gonna bring Dr. Shepherd to see you. 209 00:09:48,400 --> 00:09:51,631 OK? Dr. Shepherd. OK? 210 00:09:51,703 --> 00:09:53,170 He's the brain specialist. 211 00:09:53,238 --> 00:09:54,865 ![pic](Jamie) Mommy and Daddy. 212 00:09:54,940 --> 00:09:58,535 Doctor? Is he good, this Dr. Shepherd? 213 00:09:59,544 --> 00:10:01,569 At just about everything. 214 00:10:03,315 --> 00:10:05,715 ![pic](Bailey) I assume the lady needs her keys 215 00:10:05,784 --> 00:10:08,184 to leave this guy's sorry ass behind. 216 00:10:08,253 --> 00:10:10,517 - Yeah. - Well, help her out. 217 00:10:10,589 --> 00:10:11,988 He needs a bronchoscopy. 218 00:10:12,057 --> 00:10:13,490 See one, do one, teach one. 219 00:10:13,558 --> 00:10:16,026 You've seen one. It's time to do one. 220 00:10:16,094 --> 00:10:18,460 Alone? Seriously? I was. I was out of line. 800 00:36:47,985 --> 00:36:50,215 Somebody should have taken responsibility. 801 00:36:50,287 --> 00:36:52,551 It should have been the guy doing the cutting. 802 00:36:52,623 --> 00:36:53,783 It should have been me. 803 00:36:53,857 --> 00:36:56,291 You didn't deserve what happened to you today. 804 00:36:56,360 --> 00:36:58,419 You did the right thing, code or no code. 805 00:36:59,196 --> 00:37:01,187 ![pic](Scoffing) 806 00:37:08,605 --> 00:37:11,472 You saw me leave the house this morning, didn't you? 807 00:37:11,542 --> 00:37:12,736 Oh, was that you? 808 00:37:12,809 --> 00:37:14,470 Hmm. 809 00:37:16,179 --> 00:37:18,647 I'm not using her. 810 00:37:18,715 --> 00:37:20,615 And I don't favor her. 811 00:37:22,386 --> 00:37:24,013 She's pretty great, you know. 812 00:37:24,621 --> 00:37:26,179 Mm-hmm. 813 00:37:26,256 --> 00:37:28,986 So let's go tell Jamie's parents she's gonna be fine, 814 00:37:29,059 --> 00:37:31,619 barring any complications. 815 00:37:31,695 --> 00:37:34,027 [George clears throat] 816 00:37:34,097 --> 00:37:35,758 Did you fix me? 817 00:37:35,832 --> 00:37:37,857 No, not completely. 818 00:37:37,935 --> 00:37:41,063 So I won't get fat? 819 00:37:41,138 --> 00:37:42,628 No. 820 00:37:43,240 --> 00:37:46,505 Oh. That's awesome. 821 00:37:46,577 --> 00:37:48,909 Claire, I've asked social services 822 00:37:48,979 --> 00:37:50,708 to contact your parents. 823 00:37:51,782 --> 00:37:52,908 Why? 824 00:37:52,983 --> 00:37:54,848 ![pic](Meredith) They can help you. 825 00:37:54,918 --> 00:37:56,078 With what? 826 00:37:56,153 --> 00:37:58,417 ![pic](Sighing) 827 00:37:58,488 --> 00:38:00,046 You don't know this yet, 828 00:38:00,958 --> 00:38:04,917 but life isn't supposed to be like this. 829 00:38:04,995 --> 00:38:07,122 It's not supposed to be this hard. 830 00:38:12,769 --> 00:38:13,895 ![pic](Sighs) 831 00:38:13,971 --> 00:38:16,132 Time of death, 20:49. 832 00:38:19,076 --> 00:38:22,409 The first guy I ever met out here from back home. 833 00:38:35,592 --> 00:38:37,856 I thought you'd be asleep by now. 834 00:38:37,928 --> 00:38:39,919 Yeah, well, I'm not. 835 00:38:41,431 --> 00:38:43,991 If you wait a few minutes, you can have a piece of cake. 836 00:38:44,067 --> 00:38:45,728 Baked it chock-full of love. 837 00:38:45,802 --> 00:38:48,930 Actually, chock-full of unrelenting, all-consuming rage 838 00:38:49,006 --> 00:38:51,736 and hostility, but it's still tasty. 839 00:38:51,808 --> 00:38:54,538 - So you know? - I know. 840 00:38:54,611 --> 00:38:56,772 Well, do you want the long, sordid version, 841 00:38:56,847 --> 00:38:59,645 or the short version, where I started sleeping with a guy 842 00:38:59,716 --> 00:39:01,377 who turned out to be my boss? 843 00:39:01,451 --> 00:39:03,282 Neither. 844 00:39:03,353 --> 00:39:05,082 Izzie, cut me some slack here. 845 00:39:05,155 --> 00:39:07,623 No. You went to Dartmouth. 846 00:39:07,691 --> 00:39:09,249 Your mother is Ellis Grey. 847 00:39:09,326 --> 00:39:11,385 You grew up... Look at this house! 848 00:39:11,461 --> 00:39:13,224 You know, you walk into the OR, 849 00:39:13,296 --> 00:39:16,231 and there isn't anyone who doubts that you should be there. 850 00:39:16,299 --> 00:39:19,200 I grew up in a trailer park. I went to state school. 851 00:39:19,269 --> 00:39:22,466 I put myself through med school by posing in my underwear. 852 00:39:22,539 --> 00:39:26,168 You know, I walk into the OR, and everyone hopes I'm the nurse. 853 00:39:26,243 --> 00:39:28,711 Y-you have their respect without even trying, 854 00:39:28,779 --> 00:39:30,940 and you're throwing it away for... what? 855 00:39:31,014 --> 00:39:32,140 A few good surgeries? 856 00:39:32,215 --> 00:39:33,546 No. 857 00:39:33,617 --> 00:39:35,175 It's not about the surgeries. 858 00:39:35,252 --> 00:39:36,810 It's not about getting ahead. 859 00:39:36,887 --> 00:39:38,616 ![pic](Izzie) Then what? 860 00:39:38,689 --> 00:39:40,418 A little hot sex? 861 00:39:40,490 --> 00:39:43,482 You're willing to ruin your credibility over that? 862 00:39:44,194 --> 00:39:47,220 I mean, Meredith, what the hell are you doing? 863 00:39:50,734 --> 00:39:52,793 Oh, my God. 864 00:39:52,869 --> 00:39:54,302 You're falling for him. 865 00:39:54,371 --> 00:39:56,271 I am not. 866 00:39:56,339 --> 00:39:57,499 Oh, you so are. 867 00:39:57,574 --> 00:39:59,906 No, I'm not. 868 00:39:59,976 --> 00:40:02,206 You so are. 869 00:40:02,279 --> 00:40:05,112 Damn it, you poor girl. 870 00:40:06,583 --> 00:40:09,279 You know, it's just that he's just so... 871 00:40:09,352 --> 00:40:13,311 And I'm just... I'm having a hard time. 872 00:40:13,390 --> 00:40:16,518 Wow, you're all, uh, mushy and... 873 00:40:16,593 --> 00:40:19,994 warm and... full of secret feelings. 874 00:40:24,835 --> 00:40:28,100 I hate you! And your cake. 875 00:40:28,171 --> 00:40:30,105 My cake is good. 876 00:40:31,641 --> 00:40:34,667 So, um, how hot is the sex? 877 00:40:35,846 --> 00:40:36,835 Izzie. 878 00:40:36,913 --> 00:40:39,438 What? Come on, I'm not getting any. 879 00:40:39,516 --> 00:40:42,076 Help a girl out with a few details. 880 00:40:42,152 --> 00:40:44,313 [Rowing machine whirring] 881 00:40:48,091 --> 00:40:49,183 ![pic](Bangs) 882 00:40:49,259 --> 00:40:51,386 ![pic](Meredith) Maybe we like the pain. 883 00:40:53,563 --> 00:40:55,554 Pooh. 884 00:40:55,632 --> 00:40:56,929 How's she doing? 885 00:40:57,000 --> 00:40:58,797 - Good. - Good. 886 00:40:59,569 --> 00:41:01,594 ![pic](Meredith) Maybe we're wired that way. 887 00:41:05,008 --> 00:41:06,498 Cristina? 888 00:41:13,617 --> 00:41:16,950 Because without it, I don't know... 889 00:41:20,390 --> 00:41:22,551 ... maybe we just wouldn't feel real. 890 00:41:33,103 --> 00:41:34,536 You know, we could just... 891 00:41:34,604 --> 00:41:36,037 Sleep? 892 00:41:36,840 --> 00:41:39,434 We could, yeah, if... if you want to. 893 00:41:39,509 --> 00:41:40,999 Yeah? 894 00:41:44,981 --> 00:41:46,744 ![pic](Meredith) What's that saying? 895 00:41:46,817 --> 00:41:49,217 "Why do I keep hitting myself with a hammer?" 896 00:41:49,719 --> 00:41:52,210 Oh, thank God. 897 00:41:53,223 --> 00:41:56,715 "Because it feels so good when I stop. " 9999 00:00:0,500 --> 00:00:2,00 www.tvsubtitles.net

title: learning record

content:
我想在vim里查看英语单词的解释

有这个项目：https://github.com/felixonmars/ydcv

把单词传给这个py就可以

我也知道`@0` 存放了当前复制的内容

可是vim里没法吧`@0`传出去，知乎的回答 http://www.zhihu.com/question/20515333

我写了这个给vim文件
```bash
if exists("*Dict")
else
    function! Dict()
        let translated = system("~/git/ydcv/ydcv.py " .  @0)
        echo translated
    endfunction
endif
```
完美解决

content: 1 00:00:01,389 --> 00:00:03,914 Previously on Grey's Anatomy: 2 00:00:03,992 --> 00:00:06,119 - We had sex, once. - Go out with me. 3 00:00:06,194 --> 00:00:08,594 You know you're my boss, it's against the rules. 4 00:00:08,663 --> 00:00:11,223 Do you like Izzie? Is that what this is about? 5 00:00:11,299 --> 00:00:13,164 She's not the one I'm attracted to. 6 00:00:13,234 --> 00:00:14,326 So there's a one. 7 00:00:14,402 --> 00:00:16,927 Ever been attracted to someone you couldn't have? 8 00:00:17,005 --> 00:00:19,064 Meredith. 9 00:00:19,140 --> 00:00:21,199 - Just coffee. - Good. 10 00:00:21,276 --> 00:00:22,641 - OK. - OK. 11 00:00:22,711 --> 00:00:26,772 ![pic](Woman) Your mother's Alzheimer's is advancing. While she's lucid enough, 12 00:00:26,848 --> 00:00:29,578 - she needs to sign everything to you. - Me? 13 00:00:31,052 --> 00:00:33,179 Thanks for the coffee. 14 00:00:35,557 --> 00:00:37,991 ![pic](Derek) So you blew me off for a bottle of tequila. 15 00:00:38,059 --> 00:00:40,425 That's not nearly as much fun to wake up to. 16 00:00:40,495 --> 00:00:43,191 - ![pic](Knocking) - Mind moving this tail wagon? 17 00:00:43,264 --> 00:00:44,663 You're blocking me in. 18 00:00:44,733 --> 00:00:45,995 ![pic](Sighing) 19 00:00:47,769 --> 00:00:49,737 ![pic](Meredith) A couple hundred years ago, 20 00:00:49,804 --> 00:00:51,829 Benjamin Franklin shared with the world 21 00:00:51,906 --> 00:00:54,170 the secret of his success. 22 00:00:54,242 --> 00:00:56,472 "Never leave that till tomorrow, " he said, 23 00:00:56,544 --> 00:00:58,034 "which you can do today." 24 00:00:58,113 --> 00:01:00,809 - [- Jem: Save Me] - [Thunder rumbling] 25 00:01:01,983 --> 00:01:03,974 [Alarm buzzing] 26 00:01:05,186 --> 00:01:07,780 This is the man who discovered electricity. 27 00:01:07,856 --> 00:01:10,689 You'd think more of us would listen to what he had to say. 28 00:01:15,897 --> 00:01:18,764 I don't know why we put things off, 29 00:01:18,833 --> 00:01:20,824 but if I had to guess, 30 00:01:20,902 --> 00:01:23,700 I'd say it has a lot to do with fear. 31 00:01:25,407 --> 00:01:30,640 Fear of failure, fear of pain, fear of rejection. 32 00:01:35,383 --> 00:01:37,647 Wouldn't it be easier to just ask her out? 33 00:01:37,719 --> 00:01:39,949 [Thunder rumbling] 34 00:01:47,262 --> 00:01:49,253 [Alarm buzzing] 35 00:01:52,000 --> 00:01:54,195 - She's gonna be late. - Maybe not. 36 00:01:55,403 --> 00:01:57,530 - [Izzie gasping] - We should wait for her. 37 00:01:57,605 --> 00:01:59,163 Definitely not. 38 00:01:59,240 --> 00:02:01,731 I'm not her mother, and you are not her boyfriend. 39 00:02:01,810 --> 00:02:03,141 Not yet, anyway. 40 00:02:03,211 --> 00:02:05,577 Stop, OK? I told you I'm not interested. 41 00:02:05,647 --> 00:02:06,944 Life is short, George. 42 00:02:07,015 --> 00:02:09,848 Do you really want to die before you ever ask her out? 43 00:02:09,918 --> 00:02:12,409 I do not want to ask her out. 44 00:02:12,487 --> 00:02:14,352 Do you really want to die a liar? 45 00:02:14,422 --> 00:02:17,414 I'm not... I'm not dying. 46 00:02:18,626 --> 00:02:21,618 ![pic](Meredith) Sometimes, the fear is just of making a decision. 47 00:02:24,299 --> 00:02:26,631 Because, what if you're wrong? 48 00:02:26,701 --> 00:02:29,169 What if you're making a mistake you can't undo? 49 00:02:30,271 --> 00:02:31,431 Crap. 50 00:02:31,506 --> 00:02:32,700 Crap? 51 00:02:32,774 --> 00:02:34,332 Hi. I'm late. 52 00:02:34,409 --> 00:02:35,740 You're avoiding me. 53 00:02:35,810 --> 00:02:37,402 Yes, but also late. 54 00:02:37,479 --> 00:02:39,242 Oh, are we going to talk about this? 55 00:02:39,314 --> 00:02:40,338 No. 56 00:02:40,415 --> 00:02:42,280 About us and Bailey and what she saw? 57 00:02:42,350 --> 00:02:43,817 I don't need to talk about it. 58 00:02:43,885 --> 00:02:45,944 I experienced it, naked. 59 00:02:46,020 --> 00:02:47,510 This is getting complicated. 60 00:02:47,589 --> 00:02:48,817 Complicated for me. 61 00:02:48,890 --> 00:02:51,085 I'm the intern sleeping with the attending. 62 00:02:51,159 --> 00:02:53,059 Bailey isn't speaking to me anymore. 63 00:02:53,127 --> 00:02:55,152 Not that that's a bad thing. 64 00:02:55,230 --> 00:02:57,198 If I was a better guy, I'd walk away. 65 00:02:57,265 --> 00:02:59,130 Yes, you would. 66 00:03:00,602 --> 00:03:02,593 Do you want me to be a better guy? 67 00:03:02,670 --> 00:03:04,103 Yes. 68 00:03:05,707 --> 00:03:07,038 No. 69 00:03:08,243 --> 00:03:10,006 Crap. 70 00:03:10,078 --> 00:03:11,909 I'm late. 71 00:03:11,980 --> 00:03:13,504 Take your time. 72 00:03:14,449 --> 00:03:15,882 Think about it. 73 00:03:15,950 --> 00:03:16,939 [- Psapp: Chapter] 74 00:03:17,018 --> 00:03:18,485 [Elevator bell dinging] 75 00:03:20,355 --> 00:03:22,983 That was definitely worth being late. 76 00:03:23,057 --> 00:03:24,684 ![pic](Sighs) 77 00:03:24,759 --> 00:03:26,158 Thanks. 78 00:03:29,497 --> 00:03:31,328 Is this a? 79 00:03:31,399 --> 00:03:32,923 Should we talk about this? 80 00:03:35,036 --> 00:03:36,628 Yeah, definitely. 81 00:03:48,917 --> 00:03:50,908 - ![pic](Meredith) You're late. - So are you. 82 00:03:50,985 --> 00:03:53,579 I know, and I can't afford to piss off Bailey any more. 83 00:03:53,655 --> 00:03:55,088 Do you think she told anyone? 84 00:03:55,156 --> 00:03:56,783 - About you and McDreamy? - Yeah. 85 00:03:56,858 --> 00:03:58,223 No, he's her boss too. 86 00:03:58,293 --> 00:04:01,319 If they find out, what can they? Can they kick me out, or? 87 00:04:01,396 --> 00:04:04,297 No... Not officially. 88 00:04:04,365 --> 00:04:07,300 You'll just get edged out, 89 00:04:07,368 --> 00:04:10,963 blacklisted, banned from his surgeries, 90 00:04:11,039 --> 00:04:12,973 passed over for chief resident. 91 00:04:13,041 --> 00:04:16,272 ![pic](Sighing) It'll be humiliating, but you'll live. 92 00:04:16,344 --> 00:04:18,209 I have to end it. 93 00:04:18,279 --> 00:04:21,339 I definitely have to end it. 94 00:04:21,416 --> 00:04:24,544 - I have to end it, right? - Meredith, shut up. 95 00:04:24,619 --> 00:04:26,018 What? 96 00:04:26,654 --> 00:04:29,282 ![pic](Meredith) Did you seriously just tell me to shut up? 97 00:04:29,357 --> 00:04:30,346 Oh, please. 98 00:04:30,425 --> 00:04:33,451 You got a hot doctor who likes to make you open up, and say "ahh." 99 00:04:33,528 --> 00:04:35,860 It's the American dream, stop whining about it. 100 00:04:35,930 --> 00:04:38,364 No. No good can come from sleeping with your boss. 101 00:04:38,433 --> 00:04:40,560 - Cristina, you're late. - So is Meredith. 102 00:04:40,635 --> 00:04:42,762 ![pic](Meredith) Whatever it is we're afraid of, 103 00:04:42,837 --> 00:04:44,498 one thing holds true. 104 00:04:44,572 --> 00:04:46,938 That, by the time the pain of not doing a thing 105 00:04:47,008 --> 00:04:48,942 gets worse than the fear of doing it, 106 00:04:49,010 --> 00:04:51,638 it can feel like we're carrying around a giant tumor. 107 00:04:51,713 --> 00:04:54,614 When we walk in this door, you will maintain decorum. 108 00:04:54,682 --> 00:04:57,242 You will not laugh, vomit, or drop your jaw. 109 00:04:57,318 --> 00:04:59,081 Are we understood? [Door opening] 110 00:04:59,153 --> 00:05:01,178 - Why would we laugh? - Oh, just you wait. 111 00:05:01,255 --> 00:05:03,086 Good morning, Miss Connors. 112 00:05:03,157 --> 00:05:04,886 [Miss Connors] Good morning. 113 00:05:07,128 --> 00:05:08,561 What is it? 114 00:05:09,497 --> 00:05:11,260 Tumor. 115 00:05:11,332 --> 00:05:14,699 ![pic](Meredith) And you thought I was speaking metaphorically. 116 00:05:18,906 --> 00:05:20,897 [- Psapp: Nobody Knows] 117 00:05:45,466 --> 00:05:47,195 Good morning, Annie. How are you? 118 00:05:47,268 --> 00:05:49,793 This is Dr. Bailey, and these are my fellow interns. 119 00:05:49,871 --> 00:05:52,169 Dr. Karev, we refer to patients as "mister"... 120 00:05:52,240 --> 00:05:54,231 I told him to call me "Annie." 121 00:05:54,308 --> 00:05:56,799 "Miss Connors" makes me feel old and fat, 122 00:05:56,878 --> 00:06:00,575 which I am, but why feel that way? 123 00:06:00,648 --> 00:06:02,343 ![pic](Burke) Good morning. 124 00:06:02,417 --> 00:06:05,648 Annie, this is Dr. Burke. ![pic](Whispering) Awesome surgeon. 125 00:06:06,754 --> 00:06:08,085 Dr. Karev. 126 00:06:08,156 --> 00:06:12,320 Annie Connors is a 43-year-old woman who presented last night 127 00:06:12,393 --> 00:06:15,692 with progressive shortness of breath the past three months. 128 00:06:15,763 --> 00:06:18,561 Found to have a very large tumor 129 00:06:18,633 --> 00:06:21,227 of unknown origin pressed against her diaphragm. 130 00:06:21,302 --> 00:06:22,462 Stable vital signs. 131 00:06:22,537 --> 00:06:24,402 Scheduled for CT this morning, sir. 132 00:06:24,472 --> 00:06:27,270 Thank you, Dr. Karev. Are you at all claustrophobic? 133 00:06:27,341 --> 00:06:29,673 ![pic](Annie) I've been housebound for the last year. 134 00:06:29,744 --> 00:06:31,371 How claustrophobic could I be? 135 00:06:32,580 --> 00:06:35,640 ![pic](Burke) All right. Dr. Stevens is going to take you up for a CT. 136 00:06:35,717 --> 00:06:37,685 It'll give us a better look at the tumor, 137 00:06:37,752 --> 00:06:40,846 - and we'll know how to proceed. - Could someone tell my mom? 138 00:06:40,922 --> 00:06:43,220 She'll worry if she gets back, and I'm not here. 139 00:06:43,291 --> 00:06:45,384 Yeah, of course. Of course. 140 00:06:45,460 --> 00:06:49,226 And would it be possible for Alex to take me instead? 141 00:06:49,297 --> 00:06:51,822 I mean, he... 142 00:06:51,899 --> 00:06:53,730 He's just so fun to look at. 143 00:06:53,801 --> 00:06:55,894 ![pic](Chuckling) Annie. 144 00:06:55,970 --> 00:06:58,370 ![pic](Burke) Sure. Sure, Ms. Connors. 145 00:06:58,439 --> 00:06:59,963 Excuse me. 146 00:07:02,043 --> 00:07:04,034 ![pic](Izzie) How much do you think it weighs? 147 00:07:04,112 --> 00:07:05,136 ![pic](George) 60 pounds. 148 00:07:05,213 --> 00:07:07,340 More. She's carrying a whole extra person. 149 00:07:07,415 --> 00:07:09,747 This one's going in the books. I've got to get in. 150 00:07:09,817 --> 00:07:12,149 I almost did. Have you ever seen Alex like that? 151 00:07:12,220 --> 00:07:13,653 He actually seemed sincere. 152 00:07:13,721 --> 00:07:15,518 "Seemed" being the operative word. 153 00:07:15,590 --> 00:07:17,057 He was on call when she came in. 154 00:07:17,125 --> 00:07:18,922 I am never leaving this place again. 155 00:07:18,993 --> 00:07:20,426 Let's move, people. 156 00:07:20,495 --> 00:07:23,225 Ms. Connor's surgery, should we choose to proceed, 157 00:07:23,297 --> 00:07:26,095 will take most, if not all, of the surgeons off the floor, 158 00:07:26,167 --> 00:07:27,464 which means you people 159 00:07:27,535 --> 00:07:29,935 will have to work extra hard not to kill anyone, 160 00:07:30,004 --> 00:07:32,404 'cause we won't be there to fix your mistakes. 161 00:07:32,473 --> 00:07:34,065 ![pic](Man) Dr. Burke. 162 00:07:34,142 --> 00:07:37,305 [Woman over PA] Trauma team to OR one. Trauma team to OR one. 163 00:07:37,378 --> 00:07:38,709 I really want in on this. 164 00:07:38,780 --> 00:07:40,577 I thought we weren't talking. 165 00:07:40,648 --> 00:07:42,843 I'm not talking. I'm just saying. 166 00:07:42,917 --> 00:07:44,509 ![pic](Sighing) 167 00:07:44,585 --> 00:07:46,576 Find her mother, get a family history, 168 00:07:46,654 --> 00:07:48,849 and I'll tell Bailey. 169 00:07:50,691 --> 00:07:53,353 ![pic](Izzie) Mr. Harper had a coronary bypass yesterday. 170 00:07:53,427 --> 00:07:55,657 His blood pressure, currently 100l65. 171 00:07:55,730 --> 00:07:58,597 It was running low overnight down to 70l30, 172 00:07:58,666 --> 00:08:00,463 but responded to medication. 173 00:08:00,535 --> 00:08:03,902 Postoperative labs show a crit of 30 and normal coagulation. 174 00:08:03,971 --> 00:08:06,633 Chest-tube output has halted over the last two hours. 175 00:08:06,707 --> 00:08:08,197 ![pic](Bailey) What's your plan? 176 00:08:08,276 --> 00:08:11,109 Chest x-ray and check the tube for possible occlusion. 177 00:08:11,179 --> 00:08:12,942 Good. He's doing fine. 178 00:08:13,014 --> 00:08:15,414 ![pic](Exhaling) Thank you. 179 00:08:24,358 --> 00:08:27,521 I know you think I like Meredith, but I don't like Meredith. 180 00:08:27,595 --> 00:08:28,584 What? 181 00:08:28,663 --> 00:08:31,097 No. I like Meredith. Obviously, I like Meredith. 182 00:08:31,165 --> 00:08:33,224 I just... Suction! 764 00:36:31,043 --> 00:36:32,567 The pressure's dropping. 765 00:36:32,645 --> 00:36:34,169 Where the hell is the blood?! 766 00:36:38,084 --> 00:36:40,678 Somebody grab that. Push it back, George. Come on. 767 00:36:40,753 --> 00:36:42,516 [All panting] 768 00:36:44,590 --> 00:36:46,922 Oh, God. Just squeeze it off right there. 769 00:36:46,993 --> 00:36:48,927 Here we go. 770 00:36:53,900 --> 00:36:55,595 Is that O-negative for OR 1? 771 00:36:55,668 --> 00:36:56,692 Uh-huh, OR 1. 772 00:36:56,769 --> 00:36:59,169 OR 1, right? I got it! I got it! 773 00:37:02,174 --> 00:37:04,005 Some suction, please, in here, now. 774 00:37:04,076 --> 00:37:06,271 - ![pic](flatlining) - We're losing her now. 775 00:37:06,345 --> 00:37:09,280 Look at this. Come on. 776 00:37:09,348 --> 00:37:11,339 [Flatlining continues] 777 00:37:24,630 --> 00:37:27,360 Oh, come on! Come on! 778 00:37:27,433 --> 00:37:29,424 ![pic](Grunting) 779 00:37:35,341 --> 00:37:37,172 Come on! 780 00:37:37,243 --> 00:37:39,234 ![pic](Panting) 781 00:37:47,153 --> 00:37:49,144 [Monitor switches off] 782 00:37:56,796 --> 00:37:59,959 Time of death is 11:42. 783 00:38:16,182 --> 00:38:17,945 I got it! 784 00:38:28,861 --> 00:38:31,659 [- Butterfly Boucher: Never Leave Your Heart Alone] 785 00:38:40,039 --> 00:38:43,236 ![pic](Meredith) The early bird catches the worm. 786 00:38:43,309 --> 00:38:46,301 A stitch in time saves nine. 787 00:38:47,813 --> 00:38:48,973 Messy. 788 00:38:49,048 --> 00:38:50,379 I'm sorry. 789 00:38:50,449 --> 00:38:52,940 Don't be. You saved his life. 790 00:39:01,794 --> 00:39:04,627 ![pic](Meredith) He who hesitates is lost. 791 00:39:17,810 --> 00:39:20,335 We can't pretend we haven't been told. 792 00:39:20,980 --> 00:39:22,845 We've all heard the proverbs, 793 00:39:22,915 --> 00:39:25,076 heard the philosophers, 794 00:39:25,151 --> 00:39:29,554 heard our grandparents warning us about wasted time, 795 00:39:29,622 --> 00:39:33,023 heard the damn poets urging us to seize the day. 796 00:39:34,627 --> 00:39:39,462 Still, sometimes, we have to see for ourselves. 797 00:39:53,112 --> 00:39:55,171 I'm not doing you any more favors. 798 00:39:55,247 --> 00:39:56,612 This was it. 799 00:39:56,682 --> 00:39:59,150 I've been holding up 50 pounds of tumor 800 00:39:59,218 --> 00:40:00,776 for the past 12 hours. 801 00:40:00,853 --> 00:40:02,548 My back's going to need traction, 802 00:40:02,621 --> 00:40:04,612 and the patient died anyways. 803 00:40:04,690 --> 00:40:07,250 And you think you did me a favor? 804 00:40:07,326 --> 00:40:09,351 Look, I'm just... 805 00:40:10,730 --> 00:40:12,561 What is this... 806 00:40:13,599 --> 00:40:15,794 ...that we're doing here? 807 00:40:15,868 --> 00:40:17,699 What is it? 808 00:40:21,073 --> 00:40:22,870 You need a definition? 809 00:40:22,942 --> 00:40:25,570 You really want to be that guy? 810 00:40:29,648 --> 00:40:32,378 ![pic](Meredith) We have to make our own mistakes. 811 00:40:33,819 --> 00:40:35,810 Lock the door. 812 00:40:38,157 --> 00:40:41,320 We have to learn our own lessons. 813 00:40:41,393 --> 00:40:43,088 Have you seen Meredith? 814 00:40:43,162 --> 00:40:46,029 Save yourself the misery, man. She's off the market. 815 00:40:46,098 --> 00:40:49,033 What? No, that's not... We're just friends. 816 00:40:49,101 --> 00:40:50,090 Whatever. 817 00:40:50,169 --> 00:40:52,660 But she's not. I mean, if she was seeing someone, 818 00:40:52,738 --> 00:40:54,729 I live with her, I would know it. 819 00:41:04,116 --> 00:41:06,949 ![pic](Meredith) We have to sweep today's possibility 820 00:41:07,019 --> 00:41:10,352 under tomorrow's rug until we can't anymore, 821 00:41:10,422 --> 00:41:13,414 until we finally understand for ourselves 822 00:41:13,492 --> 00:41:15,892 what Benjamin Franklin meant. 823 00:41:18,164 --> 00:41:20,758 That knowing is better than wondering. 824 00:41:26,238 --> 00:41:28,399 That waking is better than sleeping. 825 00:41:33,546 --> 00:41:37,243 I, um, know this place 826 00:41:37,316 --> 00:41:39,443 where there's an amazing view 827 00:41:39,518 --> 00:41:42,578 of sunrise over the ferryboats. 828 00:41:45,558 --> 00:41:47,219 I have a thing for ferryboats. 829 00:41:48,627 --> 00:41:50,219 I remember. 830 00:42:01,674 --> 00:42:04,199 And that even the biggest failure, 831 00:42:04,276 --> 00:42:07,677 even the worst, most intractable mistake 832 00:42:07,746 --> 00:42:09,805 beats the hell out of never trying. 9999 00:00:0,500 --> 00:00:2,00 www.tvsubtitles.net
title: Gre's Anatomy S01E06

content: 1 00:00:00,981 --> 00:00:02,539 [- The Ditty Bops: Wake Up] 2 00:00:03,784 --> 00:00:07,276 ![pic](Meredith) Remember when you were a kid, and your biggest worry was, 3 00:00:07,354 --> 00:00:10,221 like, if you'd get a bike for your birthday 4 00:00:10,290 --> 00:00:13,316 or if you'd get to eat cookies for breakfast? 5 00:00:14,461 --> 00:00:18,329 Being an adult, totally overrated. 6 00:00:19,766 --> 00:00:21,757 I mean, seriously, don't be fooled 7 00:00:21,835 --> 00:00:23,826 by all the hot shoes and the great sex 8 00:00:23,904 --> 00:00:26,737 and the no parents anywhere telling you what to do. 9 00:00:27,708 --> 00:00:30,302 Adulthood is responsibility. 10 00:00:30,377 --> 00:00:34,040 The lawyer has been managing her estate with a limited power of attorney, 11 00:00:34,114 --> 00:00:36,344 but your mother's Alzheimer's is advancing. 12 00:00:36,416 --> 00:00:38,714 So while she's still lucid enough to consent, 13 00:00:38,785 --> 00:00:40,946 she needs to sign everything over to you. 14 00:00:41,888 --> 00:00:43,185 Me? 15 00:00:45,892 --> 00:00:49,055 ![pic](Meredith) Responsibility, it really does suck. 16 00:00:49,129 --> 00:00:51,825 Look, I haven't slept in 48 hours. 17 00:00:51,898 --> 00:00:54,924 I'm getting my first shot at heart surgery this morning. 18 00:00:55,001 --> 00:00:56,366 I'm missing rounds. 19 00:00:56,436 --> 00:01:00,532 Are you sure there isn't anybody here, or the attorney? 20 00:01:00,607 --> 00:01:03,098 I mean, do I really have to be the one to handle this? 21 00:01:03,176 --> 00:01:06,168 We're talking about her estate, finances, medical care. 22 00:01:06,246 --> 00:01:08,714 You want to leave her life in someone else's hands? 23 00:01:08,782 --> 00:01:10,511 She's your mother. 24 00:01:11,818 --> 00:01:14,218 ![pic](Meredith) Really, really sucks. 25 00:01:15,389 --> 00:01:18,324 Adults have to be places and do things 26 00:01:18,392 --> 00:01:21,327 and earn a living and pay the rent. 27 00:01:21,395 --> 00:01:23,295 And if you're training to be a surgeon, 28 00:01:23,363 --> 00:01:25,797 holding a human heart in your hands... 29 00:01:26,833 --> 00:01:28,164 Hello! 30 00:01:28,235 --> 00:01:30,897 Talk about responsibility! 31 00:01:33,774 --> 00:01:37,369 - What was that, Dr. Grey? - Sorry, it slipped. My hands... 32 00:01:38,412 --> 00:01:39,674 It's OK. I'm done. 33 00:01:40,213 --> 00:01:44,377 You can release Mrs. Patterson's heart now, very gently. 34 00:01:47,387 --> 00:01:51,084 All right. Let's warm her up. Get her off bypass. 35 00:01:51,158 --> 00:01:55,561 Kind of makes bikes and cookies look really, really good, doesn't it? 36 00:01:55,629 --> 00:01:57,256 I wish I could hold a heart. 37 00:01:57,330 --> 00:01:58,991 A monkey could hold a heart. 38 00:01:59,065 --> 00:02:00,896 You're mad Burke didn't ask you. 39 00:02:00,967 --> 00:02:03,367 George, I need more ice and chips. 40 00:02:03,437 --> 00:02:06,429 - Who else did you invite? - We said the list was jocks only: 41 00:02:06,506 --> 00:02:08,201 Surgery, Trauma, Plastics. 42 00:02:08,275 --> 00:02:10,675 - Who else? - Some people from Peds. 43 00:02:10,744 --> 00:02:13,577 You invited the preschoolers to Meredith's house. 44 00:02:13,647 --> 00:02:16,741 Next thing, you'll say that you invited the shrinks. 45 00:02:17,551 --> 00:02:20,042 She invited Mental Defects. This party is DOA. 46 00:02:20,120 --> 00:02:23,612 Meredith thinks this is a small meet-your-boyfriend cocktail thing. 47 00:02:23,690 --> 00:02:26,591 - Did you clear this with her? - No, but I will. 48 00:02:27,360 --> 00:02:28,349 I promise. 49 00:02:28,428 --> 00:02:30,225 Why are you wasting the only weekend 50 00:02:30,297 --> 00:02:32,231 your boyfriend is in town on a big party? 51 00:02:32,299 --> 00:02:33,459 Is he bad in bed? 52 00:02:34,601 --> 00:02:37,195 No. I just want him to meet some of my friends. 53 00:02:37,270 --> 00:02:39,568 Right. Sixty geeks in scrubs are your friends. 54 00:02:39,639 --> 00:02:41,539 [Pager beeping] 55 00:02:41,608 --> 00:02:42,836 Ugh! 56 00:02:42,909 --> 00:02:44,501 Bad sex, sucks for you. 57 00:02:44,578 --> 00:02:47,376 - I heard there's a party tonight. - Really? A party? 58 00:02:47,447 --> 00:02:49,244 - Uh, news to me. - No party. 59 00:02:49,316 --> 00:02:50,715 We losing her or what? 60 00:02:51,718 --> 00:02:54,312 - Are the grafts? - They're open. Temperature? 61 00:02:54,387 --> 00:02:55,649 She's at 96 and rising. 62 00:02:55,722 --> 00:02:58,247 ![pic](Burke) She should be doing this on her own. 63 00:02:58,325 --> 00:02:59,622 ![pic](Flatlining) 64 00:03:02,028 --> 00:03:03,620 ![pic](Man) That's her falling. 65 00:03:03,697 --> 00:03:05,688 Continue the progressions. 66 00:03:08,368 --> 00:03:10,461 ![pic](Burke) Come on, Mrs. Patterson. Paddles. 67 00:03:10,537 --> 00:03:13,472 - ![pic](Man) Sets are below 90. - ![pic](Woman) Charge. 68 00:03:13,540 --> 00:03:15,235 Ten joules. 69 00:03:15,308 --> 00:03:16,502 Clear. 70 00:03:16,576 --> 00:03:18,339 [Flatline continuing] 71 00:03:18,411 --> 00:03:20,174 Come on, Mrs. Patterson. 72 00:03:20,247 --> 00:03:21,908 - Give me 20. - Charge. 73 00:03:21,982 --> 00:03:23,609 ![pic](Man) There. We have rhythm. 74 00:03:23,683 --> 00:03:25,116 [Monitor beeping] 75 00:03:25,185 --> 00:03:27,415 ![pic](Burke) Reluctant heart. 76 00:03:27,487 --> 00:03:29,045 All right. 77 00:03:29,122 --> 00:03:31,852 Let's close. Keep an eye on her. 78 00:03:31,925 --> 00:03:33,620 Good work, everyone. 79 00:03:34,594 --> 00:03:37,529 ![pic](Meredith) The scariest part about responsibility? 80 00:03:37,597 --> 00:03:42,694 When you screw up and let it slip right through your fingers. 81 00:03:45,405 --> 00:03:47,771 Hey, I heard you did a CABG with Burke. 82 00:03:47,841 --> 00:03:49,866 - Did you get to hold the heart? - Yeah. 83 00:03:49,943 --> 00:03:53,208 It's an amazing feeling. You never forget the first time. 84 00:03:53,280 --> 00:03:55,214 It was pretty great just to watch. 85 00:03:55,282 --> 00:03:58,410 - Vicarious thrills, you know? - Yeah. 86 00:03:58,485 --> 00:03:59,975 [Elevator bell dinging] 87 00:04:00,053 --> 00:04:02,283 [Woman over PA] Dr. Bailey to OR 7. 88 00:04:02,355 --> 00:04:05,017 Dr. Bailey to OR 7. 89 00:04:05,091 --> 00:04:06,752 - See you later. - Bye. 90 00:04:06,826 --> 00:04:08,487 [Elevator bell dinging] 91 00:04:18,004 --> 00:04:21,599 I think maybe I did something to the heart 92 00:04:21,675 --> 00:04:23,700 when I was holding it. 93 00:04:23,777 --> 00:04:26,439 I nodded off a little, squeezed it. 94 00:04:27,714 --> 00:04:30,182 Oh, please. The heart's a tough muscle. 95 00:04:30,250 --> 00:04:32,775 It can take a squeeze or two. 96 00:04:32,852 --> 00:04:36,686 My fingernail popped a glove, cut straight through. 97 00:04:37,591 --> 00:04:40,583 George, what if I punctured Mrs. Patterson's heart? 98 00:04:42,796 --> 00:04:44,821 If you had punctured it, 99 00:04:45,832 --> 00:04:48,027 you would have known when they reperfused. 100 00:04:48,101 --> 00:04:50,968 They got her heart beating. The woman's OK. 101 00:04:51,037 --> 00:04:54,097 - So I shouldn't tell Burke? - Tell him what? 102 00:04:54,174 --> 00:04:56,335 You know, um... 103 00:04:56,409 --> 00:04:58,741 ...nothing happened. The woman's OK, right? 104 00:05:00,180 --> 00:05:01,613 She's OK. 105 00:05:01,681 --> 00:05:03,672 She's fine. 106 00:05:03,750 --> 00:05:05,809 She's fine. 107 00:05:06,353 --> 00:05:08,548 [- Psapp: Nobody Knows] 108 00:05:36,583 --> 00:05:38,210 ![pic](Bailey) What do you see, George? 109 00:05:38,284 --> 00:05:41,048 ![pic](George) Hyperinflated lungs, cloudy with bullae. 110 00:05:41,121 --> 00:05:42,850 Seriously diminished capacity. 111 00:05:42,922 --> 00:05:45,390 She must be having trouble breathing. 112 00:05:45,458 --> 00:05:47,551 Course of action? 113 00:05:47,627 --> 00:05:50,619 Bullectomy procedure. Remove the bullae. Reduce pressure. 114 00:05:50,697 --> 00:05:52,790 It says here we operated on her back in '99. 115 00:05:52,866 --> 00:05:54,959 So Mrs. Drake has been through this before, 116 00:05:55,035 --> 00:05:56,593 but talk her through it anyway. 117 00:05:56,670 --> 00:05:58,661 And resist the anti-smoking lectures. 118 00:05:58,738 --> 00:06:00,933 She feels bad enough already. 119 00:06:03,109 --> 00:06:05,407 So, do you think, if they put a picture of these 120 00:06:05,478 --> 00:06:08,003 in a pack of cigarettes, people would stop smoking? 121 00:06:11,217 --> 00:06:13,879 How long has your back been hurting you? 122 00:06:13,953 --> 00:06:16,979 It's chronic. Means I have it all the time. 123 00:06:17,057 --> 00:06:19,753 I know what "chronic" means. What pain are you having? 124 00:06:19,826 --> 00:06:20,986 Oh, man, the pain's bad. 125 00:06:21,061 --> 00:06:24,861 It's like a thousand samurai warriors stabbing their swords into my spine. 126 00:06:24,931 --> 00:06:26,831 I'm allergic to aspirin, most NSAIDs. 127 00:06:26,900 --> 00:06:28,834 So maybe we'll start you on morphine. 128 00:06:28,902 --> 00:06:32,099 No. The only things that will work are Demerol 129 00:06:32,172 --> 00:06:33,833 or Dilaudid. 130 00:06:33,907 --> 00:06:35,932 A ten of Dilaudid will set me straight. 131 00:06:36,009 --> 00:06:37,874 The standard starting dose is two. 132 00:06:37,944 --> 00:06:40,469 Did you see that Tom Cruise samurai movie, hmm? 133 00:06:40,547 --> 00:06:41,844 Pow! Pow! Pow! 134 00:06:42,849 --> 00:06:45,875 Exaggerated and overly specific description of his pain. 135 00:06:45,952 --> 00:06:48,682 A self-prescription. "Pow! Pow! Pow!"? 136 00:06:48,755 --> 00:06:50,780 - He's a Dilaudid junkie. - What do you do? 137 00:06:50,857 --> 00:06:54,315 Check the database for history, refer to a program and discharge. 138 00:06:54,394 --> 00:06:56,021 After you give him something. 139 00:06:56,096 --> 00:06:57,688 That's exactly what he wants. 140 00:06:57,764 --> 00:07:00,289 You still have to treat his pain as if it were real. 141 00:07:00,366 --> 00:07:01,560 - [pager beeping] - Why? 142 00:07:01,634 --> 00:07:05,001 The first rule in pain management: Always err on the side of caution. 143 00:07:05,071 --> 00:07:06,902 He's in our care. He says he's in pain. 144 00:07:06,973 --> 00:07:09,407 Start a central line. His veins are shot. 145 00:07:17,250 --> 00:07:20,549 The surgery before was supposed to help. 146 00:07:20,620 --> 00:07:22,918 But it never felt right. 147 00:07:22,989 --> 00:07:25,583 Probably would have been a good idea to quit smoking. 148 00:07:25,658 --> 00:07:28,786 I did! Four-pack-a-day habit. It was hell. 149 00:07:28,862 --> 00:07:31,262 - Here you go, Mrs. Drake. - Didn't do any good. 150 00:07:31,331 --> 00:07:33,026 Really? Because it looked... 151 00:07:33,099 --> 00:07:34,657 I mean, from the damage, 152 00:07:34,734 --> 00:07:37,134 we all thought you probably were still smoking. 153 00:07:37,203 --> 00:07:40,434 Cold turkey, five years ago, and what did I get for my trouble? 154 00:07:40,507 --> 00:07:42,737 I still had to quit my job at the restaurant. 155 00:07:42,809 --> 00:07:44,640 But even sitting, it hurt. 156 00:07:44,711 --> 00:07:45,837 ![pic](Nurse) Here you go. 157 00:07:45,912 --> 00:07:48,881 Nobody believed me. They all said it was in my head. 158 00:07:48,948 --> 00:07:52,145 I've seen the films. It's not all in your head. 159 00:07:52,218 --> 00:07:53,776 You're right about that. 160 00:07:53,853 --> 00:07:55,115 Hey, come here. 161 00:07:56,756 --> 00:07:58,519 You're too damn young to be a doctor. 162 00:07:58,591 --> 00:08:00,684 - Hey. - What? 163 00:08:00,760 --> 00:08:02,250 I'm older than I look. 164 00:08:02,328 --> 00:08:03,727 ![pic](Chuckling) 165 00:08:03,797 --> 00:08:06,163 Do you think this is going to work this time? 166 00:08:06,232 --> 00:08:07,961 I think it's your best option. 167 00:08:08,034 --> 00:08:10,366 - Straight shooter, huh? - Yes, ma'am. 168 00:08:10,436 --> 00:08:11,835 I like that. 169 00:08:28,054 --> 00:08:29,715 Hi, Mr. Patterson. 170 00:08:29,789 --> 00:08:31,051 Hi. 171 00:08:31,124 --> 00:08:32,785 Hemodynamics stable? 172 00:08:32,859 --> 00:08:35,623 Yeah, map has stayed around 80. Cardiac output at five. 173 00:08:35,695 --> 00:08:38,755 - That's good, Dr. Grey? - That's fine, Mr. Patterson. 174 00:08:38,832 --> 00:08:40,265 But it's not good. 175 00:08:40,333 --> 00:08:42,995 Well, heart surgery takes a lot out of the patient, 176 00:08:43,069 --> 00:08:46,095 but we're monitoring your wife very carefully, 177 00:08:46,172 --> 00:08:48,003 and she should be fine. 178 00:08:52,412 --> 00:08:55,472 Mr. Sterman, let's see about getting you out of here today. 179 00:08:55,548 --> 00:08:56,742 How are you feeling? 180 00:08:56,816 --> 00:08:58,909 Pretty OK, except I don't think I ever want 181 00:08:58,985 --> 00:09:00,976 to have a bowel obstruction again. 182 00:09:01,054 --> 00:09:02,180 Really? 183 00:09:02,255 --> 00:09:05,315 We get people in here all the time requesting them. 184 00:09:05,391 --> 00:09:06,551 Oh. 185 00:09:06,626 --> 00:09:08,617 So, you keeping down clear fluids? 186 00:09:08,695 --> 00:09:11,528 And my all-time favorite question: Have you pooped yet? 187 00:09:11,598 --> 00:09:14,089 I'm not exactly sure. 188 00:09:14,167 --> 00:09:17,500 I think you'd probably know. 189 00:09:17,570 --> 00:09:18,764 Passed gas? 190 00:09:18,838 --> 00:09:20,362 Yes. 191 00:09:20,440 --> 00:09:23,273 Really? Because if I bring in my handy lie detector... 192 00:09:23,343 --> 00:09:24,537 OK, no. 193 00:09:24,611 --> 00:09:27,671 And I shouldn't try and lie, I know. 194 00:09:27,747 --> 00:09:29,977 I went to medical school. 195 00:09:30,049 --> 00:09:31,846 You went to med school? 196 00:09:31,918 --> 00:09:34,478 Yeah, dropped out my last year at clinical. 197 00:09:34,554 --> 00:09:35,748 Too many hours, 198 00:09:35,822 --> 00:09:38,620 and I was staring into the ice-cold eyes of divorce. 199 00:09:38,691 --> 00:09:40,124 Wow. 200 00:09:40,193 --> 00:09:44,789 Yeah, I do research now, and I have a life, a family. 201 00:09:45,298 --> 00:09:46,560 No offense. 202 00:09:46,633 --> 00:09:48,191 No, no, that's OK. 203 00:09:48,268 --> 00:09:51,237 I'm just one of those people who believe you can have both. 204 00:09:51,304 --> 00:09:53,397 Maybe so. 205 00:09:53,473 --> 00:09:57,136 But your first responsibility's always gonna be your patient. 206 00:09:57,210 --> 00:10:00,145 [Woman over PA] Dr. Shepherd to the ER, stat. 207 00:10:00,213 --> 00:10:02,943 Dr. Shepherd to the ER, stat. 208 00:10:03,016 --> 00:10:05,075 [- Psapp: Tiger, My Friend] 209 00:10:19,999 --> 00:10:21,227 Just coffee. 210 00:10:23,436 --> 00:10:24,425 Good. 211 00:10:24,504 --> 00:10:26,904 - OK. - OK. 212 00:11:03,743 --> 00:11:06,541 ![pic](Bailey) We call this "a spaghetti procedure." 213 00:11:06,612 --> 00:11:11,311 We cut and deflate the bullae to facilitate 214 00:11:11,384 --> 00:11:15,787 gentle manipulation of Mrs. Drake's lung. 215 00:11:15,855 --> 00:11:19,416 Dr. Bailey, do you see that? 216 00:11:19,492 --> 00:11:20,550 Sir? 217 00:11:22,729 --> 00:11:25,527 Oh, my ever-Iovin'... 218 00:11:25,598 --> 00:11:28,795 We need to open her up. I'm taking out the scope. 219 00:11:29,802 --> 00:11:31,702 You heard him, people. Let's move. 220 00:11:31,771 --> 00:11:33,204 - Lights. - Let's get set up. 221 00:11:34,073 --> 00:11:35,734 - Ten blade. - Here you go. 222 00:11:35,808 --> 00:11:37,275 Retractors. 223 00:11:37,343 --> 00:11:38,810 Retractors. 224 00:11:39,746 --> 00:11:41,407 Scalpel ready. 225 00:11:43,149 --> 00:11:44,514 Towel. 226 00:11:47,320 --> 00:11:48,810 Rib spreader. 227 00:11:51,791 --> 00:11:53,156 Suction. 228 00:12:01,834 --> 00:12:03,734 Is that a towel? 229 00:12:03,803 --> 00:12:06,567 - Get a pan. - ![pic](George) Where did that come from? 230 00:12:06,639 --> 00:12:09,904 Best guess, her surgery five years ago. 231 00:12:11,110 --> 00:12:14,910 Something careless this way comes. 232 00:12:21,721 --> 00:12:23,052 - A towel? - Not good. 233 00:12:23,122 --> 00:12:26,489 She complained of pressure on her chest. Nobody took her seriously. 234 00:12:26,559 --> 00:12:29,119 Not good for the patient, not good for the hospital. 235 00:12:29,195 --> 00:12:31,026 - Not good. - Cristina, hit the files. 236 00:12:31,097 --> 00:12:33,998 Find out everything you can about that initial operation. 237 00:12:34,067 --> 00:12:36,729 Who was in that room? Who was responsible for closing? 238 00:12:36,803 --> 00:12:40,136 George, stay with the patient. Keep her happy. She seems to like you. 239 00:12:40,206 --> 00:12:42,401 Right, OK, um, how long do you think? 240 00:12:42,475 --> 00:12:45,410 I mean, just technically, I'm off at 6:00. 241 00:12:45,478 --> 00:12:48,208 - Am I invited? - Excuse me? 242 00:12:48,281 --> 00:12:49,543 Am I invited to the party? 243 00:12:49,615 --> 00:12:50,809 Oh. 244 00:12:50,883 --> 00:12:53,647 Well, yeah. Yes, yeah, of course. 245 00:12:57,423 --> 00:13:00,187 What was I supposed to say? 246 00:13:00,259 --> 00:13:01,726 Ugh! 247 00:13:04,097 --> 00:13:07,191 OK, yeah, great. My life is crap. 545 00:30:44,956 --> 00:30:48,858 And it's my party, and I'll get drunk if I want to. 546 00:30:48,927 --> 00:30:51,555 Is, um, Izzie Stevens? 547 00:30:51,630 --> 00:30:53,860 Oh, you must be Hank. 548 00:30:53,932 --> 00:30:56,093 ![pic](Laughing) 549 00:30:56,168 --> 00:30:58,159 He's very large and hockey-like. 550 00:30:58,236 --> 00:31:00,329 No, Izzie's not here right now. 551 00:31:00,405 --> 00:31:02,270 OK. 552 00:31:02,340 --> 00:31:06,106 You and Izzie will give birth to very tall, blonde people... 553 00:31:06,178 --> 00:31:07,736 ...kind of like Barbies. 554 00:31:07,812 --> 00:31:10,804 Izzie was going to be home. She didn't say there was a party. 555 00:31:10,882 --> 00:31:14,477 Which pisses both of us off. Would you like some tequila? 556 00:31:14,553 --> 00:31:16,487 When do you think she's gonna get here? 557 00:31:16,555 --> 00:31:19,649 Don't know. Look, we're low on ice, Hank. 558 00:31:19,724 --> 00:31:22,693 - I'm serious. - So am I. 559 00:31:22,761 --> 00:31:24,092 We're interns, Hank. 560 00:31:24,162 --> 00:31:26,858 The hospital owns us. It's what we do. 561 00:31:29,668 --> 00:31:30,692 Bye. 562 00:31:30,769 --> 00:31:32,361 Nice to meet you. 563 00:31:32,437 --> 00:31:34,337 Can you guys see him through recovery? 564 00:31:34,406 --> 00:31:36,169 - Yeah, I'll take it. - No, I can do it. 565 00:31:36,241 --> 00:31:37,265 That's OK, Stevens. 566 00:31:37,342 --> 00:31:38,832 He's my patient now too. 567 00:31:38,910 --> 00:31:40,741 No, I got it. See your hockey player. 568 00:31:40,812 --> 00:31:42,245 I'm serious. 569 00:31:42,314 --> 00:31:43,645 Yeah, OK. 570 00:31:43,715 --> 00:31:46,343 I guess. Thanks, Alex. 571 00:31:46,418 --> 00:31:48,079 No problem. 572 00:31:53,792 --> 00:31:55,282 ![pic](Sighing) 573 00:32:01,499 --> 00:32:03,865 - Hey! - Hey. 574 00:32:03,935 --> 00:32:05,926 What are you doing here? 575 00:32:08,240 --> 00:32:10,401 Mmm. 576 00:32:10,475 --> 00:32:12,909 I'm sorry I didn't have a chance to call. 577 00:32:12,978 --> 00:32:14,969 My patient needed brain surgery. 578 00:32:15,046 --> 00:32:18,982 Like, we were inside his brain. How cool is that? 579 00:32:19,050 --> 00:32:21,041 ![pic](Laughing) Oh, my God. 580 00:32:23,722 --> 00:32:25,189 There's a party at your house. 581 00:32:25,257 --> 00:32:27,248 Yeah, did you get a chance to hang out? 582 00:32:27,325 --> 00:32:29,793 I wanted you to meet some of the people I work with. 583 00:32:29,861 --> 00:32:31,954 I don't care about the people you work with. 584 00:32:32,030 --> 00:32:33,497 I just want to see you. 585 00:32:33,565 --> 00:32:37,262 You didn't mind meeting the people I worked with when they were models. 586 00:32:37,335 --> 00:32:39,462 Yeah, well, when they were models, 587 00:32:39,537 --> 00:32:42,097 you actually showed up to your own parties. 588 00:32:43,275 --> 00:32:44,765 Yeah. 589 00:32:48,546 --> 00:32:52,778 This is my life now, Hank. I work 100-hour weeks. 590 00:32:52,851 --> 00:32:55,183 I can't always show up to my own parties on time. 591 00:32:55,253 --> 00:32:57,949 My patients have to come first. It's just... 592 00:32:58,023 --> 00:33:01,083 Yeah, I just flew across the entire country, 593 00:33:01,159 --> 00:33:03,059 and there's 100 people at your house. 594 00:33:03,128 --> 00:33:05,494 100 people who understand what I do all day. 595 00:33:05,563 --> 00:33:07,622 I shouldn't have to apologize for that. 596 00:33:07,699 --> 00:33:09,360 No, you shouldn't. 597 00:33:11,102 --> 00:33:14,299 [- Ivy: The Edge of the Ocean] 598 00:33:16,107 --> 00:33:19,634 Look, let's just go by the party for a little while. 599 00:33:19,711 --> 00:33:22,874 You'll really like everyone once you get a chance to know them. 600 00:33:24,449 --> 00:33:26,076 I should just go. 601 00:33:26,151 --> 00:33:27,880 Hank, come on. 602 00:33:30,455 --> 00:33:31,888 I'll call you. 603 00:34:28,413 --> 00:34:31,382 ![pic](Derek) You know, in some states, you get arrested for that. 604 00:34:44,095 --> 00:34:46,222 So, you blew me off for a bottle of tequila. 605 00:34:46,297 --> 00:34:49,391 Tequila's no good for you. Doesn't call, doesn't write. 606 00:34:49,467 --> 00:34:51,833 It's not nearly as much fun to wake up to. 607 00:35:06,184 --> 00:35:09,119 Take me for a ride, Derek. 608 00:35:14,125 --> 00:35:17,219 You know, it sounds like the party's winding down. 609 00:35:17,295 --> 00:35:18,819 - Listen to me! - What? 610 00:35:18,897 --> 00:35:21,422 We should probably sneak inside now. 611 00:35:21,499 --> 00:35:23,558 We've done enough sneaking for the night. 612 00:35:23,635 --> 00:35:25,762 It was good sneaking, but enough sneaking. 613 00:35:25,837 --> 00:35:27,930 Yeah, I'd say we're pretty good sneakers. 614 00:35:33,044 --> 00:35:35,478 You mind moving this tail wagon? 615 00:35:35,547 --> 00:35:37,538 You're blocking me in. 616 00:35:39,951 --> 00:35:42,943 Apparently not good enough. [Clearing throat] 617 00:35:43,021 --> 00:35:45,012 ![pic](Sighing) 618 00:36:11,049 --> 00:36:14,314 When's your meeting with the chief? 619 00:36:14,385 --> 00:36:15,852 In an hour. 620 00:36:20,825 --> 00:36:23,293 Holy mother of destruction. 621 00:36:23,361 --> 00:36:26,353 You missed Doctor-palooza. 622 00:36:26,431 --> 00:36:28,797 Apparently, you didn't. 623 00:36:28,867 --> 00:36:31,631 I should probably never speak to you again. 624 00:36:32,470 --> 00:36:34,165 I'm so sorry, Meredith. 625 00:36:34,239 --> 00:36:36,673 I had no idea it was going to get so... 626 00:36:36,741 --> 00:36:38,072 ![pic](Meredith) It's OK. 627 00:36:38,710 --> 00:36:40,644 Really, I don't care. 628 00:36:40,712 --> 00:36:42,475 What would I be doing, anyway? 629 00:36:42,547 --> 00:36:45,072 Preparing for your career-altering meeting. 630 00:36:45,149 --> 00:36:46,480 Sorry. 631 00:36:46,551 --> 00:36:49,019 That heart wall shouldn't have torn. 632 00:36:49,087 --> 00:36:51,214 Anything in the patient's history? 633 00:36:51,289 --> 00:36:54,281 Husband said she was in the best shape of her life. 634 00:36:54,359 --> 00:36:56,827 She lost 100 pounds last year. 635 00:36:56,895 --> 00:37:00,262 100 pounds in a year... How's her muscle mass? 636 00:37:04,168 --> 00:37:07,035 Do you even know whose that was? 637 00:37:07,105 --> 00:37:08,902 I'm hoping it was yours. 638 00:37:08,973 --> 00:37:09,962 No. 639 00:37:13,244 --> 00:37:15,542 What do you think? 640 00:37:15,613 --> 00:37:19,572 ![pic](Cristina) 50 says Meredith gets tossed out and Burke walks away clean. 641 00:37:19,651 --> 00:37:20,982 Please be nice to her. 642 00:37:21,052 --> 00:37:22,349 ![pic](Sighing) 643 00:37:22,420 --> 00:37:25,651 ![pic](Sighing) So, I have done a lot of research on this, 644 00:37:25,723 --> 00:37:28,021 and Dr. Burke has been kind enough to help me. 645 00:37:28,092 --> 00:37:30,322 And I understand my responsibility 646 00:37:30,395 --> 00:37:32,363 in what I've done wrong here. 647 00:37:32,430 --> 00:37:35,058 However, I do think the patient's history 648 00:37:35,133 --> 00:37:37,033 is significant in this case. 649 00:37:37,101 --> 00:37:39,001 She still weighs 200 pounds, 650 00:37:39,070 --> 00:37:40,833 which is why no one even noticed it. 651 00:37:40,905 --> 00:37:42,702 But with that kind of a weight drop, 652 00:37:42,774 --> 00:37:45,800 it doesn't matter how much you weigh. You're anorexic. 653 00:37:45,877 --> 00:37:48,641 Along with all that fat, she was losing heart muscle. 654 00:37:48,713 --> 00:37:50,408 That certainly could be the reason 655 00:37:50,481 --> 00:37:52,381 for a small poke to become a large tear. 656 00:37:52,450 --> 00:37:54,645 That still doesn't change the fact, though. 657 00:37:54,719 --> 00:37:57,415 The poke wasn't reported at the time of the occurrence. 658 00:37:57,488 --> 00:38:00,423 - And if I could change that... - And you can't. 659 00:38:00,491 --> 00:38:04,188 You left yourself and the hospital open to tremendous liability. 660 00:38:04,262 --> 00:38:06,924 ![pic](Burke) Not if the weight loss caused the problem. 661 00:38:06,998 --> 00:38:09,432 - I have no choice... - I've spoken to the husband. 662 00:38:09,500 --> 00:38:11,161 His wife remains stable... 663 00:38:11,235 --> 00:38:15,103 I can't take your beliefs to the bank, Dr. Burke. 664 00:38:15,173 --> 00:38:16,765 Dr. Grey made a huge error here. 665 00:38:16,841 --> 00:38:18,433 - And she reported it. - Too late. 666 00:38:18,509 --> 00:38:20,409 And in front of the patient's husband. 667 00:38:20,478 --> 00:38:22,673 But she reported it. She spoke up. 668 00:38:26,150 --> 00:38:27,947 Five years ago, as a CT fellow, 669 00:38:28,019 --> 00:38:31,011 I had a nagging feeling that I didn't check the body cavity 670 00:38:31,089 --> 00:38:33,614 of a lung patient closely enough before I closed. 671 00:38:33,691 --> 00:38:36,785 The patient seemed fine post-op, and I was in a hurry. 672 00:38:38,429 --> 00:38:41,592 And yesterday you and Dr. Bailey pulled a towel out 673 00:38:41,666 --> 00:38:43,793 from under that patient's lung. 674 00:38:43,868 --> 00:38:46,632 Why didn't I report it at an appropriate time? 675 00:38:46,704 --> 00:38:50,538 Maybe because I was afraid that I would be called into a meeting 676 00:38:50,608 --> 00:38:55,341 where some hospital lawyer's fear of liability could end my career. 677 00:38:55,413 --> 00:38:57,176 Even great doctors make mistakes, 678 00:38:57,248 --> 00:39:00,547 and when we do, we've got to have a chance to speak up 679 00:39:00,618 --> 00:39:03,052 without fear of retribution. 680 00:39:03,121 --> 00:39:05,055 Or everyone suffers. 681 00:39:05,123 --> 00:39:07,648 Dr. Grey spoke up. 682 00:39:18,870 --> 00:39:22,601 ![pic](Meredith) Responsibility: It really does suck. 683 00:39:27,512 --> 00:39:28,672 Meredith. You OK? 684 00:39:28,746 --> 00:39:31,340 - Yeah, one-month probation. - That's good. 685 00:39:31,416 --> 00:39:32,405 Yep. 686 00:39:32,483 --> 00:39:34,576 Burke saved my ass in there. 687 00:39:34,652 --> 00:39:37,985 Don't you all have something better to do? Come on, people, move! 688 00:39:39,290 --> 00:39:41,554 He was always gonna tell them about the towel. 689 00:39:41,626 --> 00:39:43,526 Just wanted to wait for the right time. 690 00:39:43,594 --> 00:39:45,858 Information is power. 691 00:39:45,930 --> 00:39:47,898 [- The Buffseeds: Sparkle Me] 692 00:40:16,527 --> 00:40:21,521 ![pic](Meredith) Once you get past the age of braces and training bras, 693 00:40:21,599 --> 00:40:23,726 responsibility doesn't go away. 694 00:40:27,004 --> 00:40:28,733 Jerry, this is Sloane. 695 00:40:28,806 --> 00:40:32,867 She's here to talk to you, if you want, about options for rehab. 696 00:40:36,380 --> 00:40:38,473 ![pic](Meredith) It can't be avoided. 697 00:40:41,119 --> 00:40:43,110 Mrs. Drake, 698 00:40:43,187 --> 00:40:46,987 I cannot begin to tell you how truly sorry I am. 699 00:40:47,058 --> 00:40:50,027 Either someone makes us face it, 700 00:40:50,094 --> 00:40:53,461 or we suffer the consequences. 701 00:41:05,143 --> 00:41:07,611 Izzie! I did it! I pooped! 702 00:41:07,678 --> 00:41:09,703 All right! 703 00:41:13,684 --> 00:41:15,709 - Missed your party? - Life as a surgeon. 704 00:41:15,787 --> 00:41:17,414 And loving every minute of it. 705 00:41:36,741 --> 00:41:41,337 ![pic](Meredith) And still, adulthood has its perks. 706 00:41:42,547 --> 00:41:44,640 Thanks for the coffee. 707 00:42:05,837 --> 00:42:07,998 ![pic](Meredith) I mean, the shoes, the sex, 708 00:42:08,072 --> 00:42:11,633 the no parents anywhere telling you what to do... 709 00:42:15,012 --> 00:42:18,914 ... that's pretty damn good. 9999 00:00:0,500 --> 00:00:2,00 www.tvsubtitles.net
title: Gre's Anatomy S01E05

content:
旅游回来，有些想要记录的东西还是记录下来，避免忘了。

本来也不是风景游，主要想亲自看看发达国家是不是真像别人说的那样。

机场很小，不用走太多路就到了，方便。国内修的超大，简直有病。

华人不少，卖手机卡那里就有，打工学生的样子，但是人很nice，很耐心的帮我们解决手机卡的问题。在国内这是不可能的，要么就是被这个国家洗去了大陆的戾气，要么就是她本来也不是大陆人。

同团有台湾人，香港人，大陆暴发户，大陆小白领（我们），大陆留学生，很有意思的组合。

南岛导游是台湾人老兵。台湾人团结，略带骄傲，在国外相互照顾。说起70年我党大阅兵，于是和他愉快的畅谈了一下我党的无耻程度；如果换了爱党被洗脑青年，估计会吵起来。

香港人谦虚礼让，甚至谦虚的过度，有些卑谦了，从不吵闹和大声说话；在国外有些很不好意思，可能因为香港最终还是沦陷了。

传统文化方面，香港人会和台湾人一起团结起来说大陆的不是，谁让我们有文化大革命呢？这个没什么好说的。草绳，井绳，繁体字，简体字，啧啧。

大陆老嬢，似乎是炒股暴发户。俺们大陆人的粗俗和无礼已经深深的刻在了骨子里面，即便在国外，不经意间还是会显露无疑。喜欢挣，喜欢抢，生怕好事好东西被人占了；吃自主时候尤其能看得出来。唯一能兴奋起来的也就是炫耀自己有多少钱了吧。

白人，嗯，姑且说白人吧。实话说对华人还是有差异的。

content: vuejs的模板闪现问题困扰我很久了 官方的例子根本没有这种情况，可是我们在实际项目中总会闪现 后来发现把js放在head里就能解决，不再会出先闪现。可是这时，vuejs实例化的代码必须要包在document.ready里了，因为这时html还没有加载出来，实例化引用不到dom 而且奇葩的是不光vuejs相关代码要放在head里，所有的js都必须放在head里，任何一个js在body里引入，都会引起模板闪现 为此，我不得不搞了这个:[tornador UI module 修改 js 嵌入位置](tornador UI module 修改 js 嵌入位置.md)，满满的都是血泪 拆解了一下，把官方例子逐渐增加引入的js，也会出现闪现了。看来和body引入的js多少有关，而且只有chrome会出现(firefox, safari都不会)，可能chrome太急于渲染html了。 想起来angularjs有个ng-cloak，专门用于解决这个问题的。一直以为vuejs有什么黑魔法，自行解决了这个问题，看来不是。 找一找，果然找到了[v-cloak](http://cn.vuejs.org/api/directives.html#v-cloak.md) ！！！！！！！ 想抽自已了，在邪路上渐行渐远.... 加入css ```css ![pic](v-cloak) { display: none; } ``` 有模板的dom里加上[v-cloak](http://cn.vuejs.org/api/directives.html#v-cloak.md) ```html (% row.title %) ``` 再也没有模板语言闪现了
title: vuejs的模板闪现问题

title: 初级程序员要求

content:
还是这里的写的好 http://rogerdudler.github.io/git-guide/index.zh.html

## 分支
分支是用来将特性开发绝缘开来的。在你创建仓库的时候，master 是“默认的”分支。在其他分支上进行开发，完成后再将它们合并到主分支上。 

创建一个叫做“feature_x”的分支，并切换过去：
`git checkout -b feature_x`

切换回主分支：
`git checkout master`

再把新建的分支删掉：
`git branch -d feature_x`
除非你将分支推送到远端仓库，不然该分支就是 不为他人所见的：

`git push origin <branch>`

要更新你的本地仓库至最新改动，执行：
`git pull`

以在你的工作目录中 获取（fetch） 并 合并（merge） 远端的改动。
要合并其他分支到你的当前分支（例如 master），执行：
`git merge <branch>`


## fork的处理
https://help.github.com/articles/syncing-a-fork/
title: git 分支

content:
需求是这样的：
    
    user_info要关联查出其它社交表里的信息，但是其它社交表可能没有这个用户
    
```bash

select u.*, COALESCE(u.slogan, tw.description, i.bio, g.bio,tu.description) as bio from user_info u 
LEFT OUTER JOIN twitter_user tw 
	ON u.user_name = tw.screen_name
LEFT OUTER JOIN instagram_user i 
	ON u.user_name = i.username
LEFT OUTER JOIN github_user g 
	ON u.user_name = g.login	
LEFT OUTER JOIN tumblr_user tu
	ON u.user_name = g.name
```

http://stackoverflow.com/questions/20858815/postgresql-same-table-left-outer-join-with-multiple-tables

引出了另外一个问题：[postgresql应如何判断空字符串](postgresql应如何判断空字符串.md)

于是改成了这样
```bash
select u.*, COALESCE(NULLIF(u.slogan,''), NULLIF(tw.description,''), NULLIF(i.bio,''), NULLIF(g.bio,''), NULLIF(tu.description,'')) as bio from user_info u 
LEFT OUTER JOIN twitter_user tw 
	ON u.user_name = tw.screen_name
LEFT OUTER JOIN instagram_user i 
	ON u.user_name = i.username
LEFT OUTER JOIN github_user g 
	ON u.user_name = g.login	
LEFT OUTER JOIN tumblr_user tu
	ON u.user_name = g.name
```
title: postgresql多表join

content:
[postgresql多表join](postgresql多表join.md) 中用了 COALESCE

但是空的string还是会被选出来`''`

得再加个`NULLIF`判断来解决
```bash

select u.*, COALESCE(NULLIF(u.slogan,''), NULLIF(tw.description,''), NULLIF(i.bio,''), NULLIF(g.bio,''), NULLIF(tu.description,'')) as bio from user_info u 
LEFT OUTER JOIN twitter_user tw 
	ON u.user_name = tw.screen_name
LEFT OUTER JOIN instagram_user i 
	ON u.user_name = i.username
LEFT OUTER JOIN github_user g 
	ON u.user_name = g.login	
LEFT OUTER JOIN tumblr_user tu
	ON u.user_name = g.name
```
title: postgresql应如何判断空字符串

content:
nerdtree 不能判断文件是否已经打开,一个文件会在多个tab里打开

按下t就知道了,一个文件会打开多个tab,时间长了就崩溃了.一大堆的tab.

~~后来发现按下enter,如果没有打开过这个文件,就会在当前tab打开替换了,如果已经打开过这个tab那么就会激活这个tab,而不是新开一个tab.~~

作者又更新修改了:
* t永远是新开tab
* 回车如果开过，那么就激活已经开过的tab；没有开过就新开；当前文件跑起来修改了，还会分割打开，相当不好。

所以我还是回退版本，用回以前的，一概用t


不完全满足我想要的,我要的是:t,如果没有开过这个文件,新开一个tab,如果开过,激活这个tab.

查看
```bash
vim ~/.vim/bundle/nerdtree/lib/nerdtree/opener.vim
```
找到
```bash
function! s:Opener._openFile()
    if self._reuse && self._reuseWindow()
        return
    endif
    ....
```
这里应该是当按下回车,并且激活Window成功,就return

改成
```bash
function! s:Opener._openFile()
    if self._reuse && self._reuseWindow()
        return
    endif
    if self._reuseWindow()
        return
    endif
```
这时按下t,就可以完全满足我的要求了:
如果没有开过这个文件,新开一个tab,如果开过,激活这个tab.
title: 让nerdtree判断文件是否打开

content:
http://hanjianwei.com/2014/09/10/webpack-package-manager-for-web/

* 官网：https://github.com/webpack
* 例子：https://github.com/webpack/webpack/tree/master/examples
* 文档：https://webpack.github.io/docs/?utm_source=github&utm_medium=readme&utm_campaign=documentation

## getting-started
官方有个教程，还可以，照着做了，有问题 http://webpack.github.io/docs/tutorials/getting-started/

到require那节
```js
+ require("!style!css!./style.css");
  document.write(require("./content.js"));
```
报错了
```bash
bigzhu:/Users/bigzhu/webpack_test/$ webpack ./entry.js bundle.js
Hash: 9f60f1641eaf55cb086a
Version: webpack 1.11.0
Time: 60ms
    Asset     Size  Chunks             Chunk Names
bundle.js  1.72 kB       0  ![pic](emitted)  main
   ![pic](0) ./entry.js 65 bytes {0} ![pic](built) [1 error]
   ![pic](1) ./style.css 0 bytes ![pic](built) ![pic](failed)
   ![pic](2) ./content.js 46 bytes {0} ![pic](built)

ERROR in ./style.css
Module parse failed: /Users/bigzhu/webpack_test/style.css Line 1: Unexpected token {
You may need an appropriate loader to handle this file type.
| body {
|     background: yellow;
| }
 @ ./entry.js 1:0-22
```

找了才知道，依赖两个另外的插件，教程也没有说要安装
```bash
npm install style-loader css-loader --save
```

自动编译到是本身就带了，方便
```bash
webpack --progress --colors --watch
```

还有一个dev server，可以监听变动并刷新浏览器
```bash
npm install webpack-dev-server -g
webpack-dev-server --progress --colors
```
改动后自动编译，并刷新页面
## 高级使用
建议的目录是这样的
```bash
/project
- /app
-- main.js
-- AppComponent.js
- /build
-- index.html
-- bundle.js (automatically built by webpack)
- webpack.config.js
```
webpack.config.js 是这样的
```js
module.exports = {
  entry: ![pic]('./app/main.js'),
  output: {
    path: './build',
    filename: 'bundle.js'
  }
};
```
package.json 是这样的
```js
{
  "name": "my-project",
  "version": "0.0.0",
  "main": "app/main.js",
  "scripts": {
    "dev": "webpack-dev-server --devtool eval --progress --colors --content-base build"
  },
  "author": "",
  "license": "ISC"
}
```
这样，只要执行`npm run dev`就可以启动webpack-dev-server了

[vuejs和webpack整合](vuejs和webpack整合.md)

content:
css 伪类这个词很奇怪, 在我看来更像标识了特殊状态的标签.

和程序中的类什么的, 一点关系都没有.

伪类用`:`跟在选择器后面,标识了一些状态

`::`表示 css3 新增的一些伪类, 建议全部都使用`::`.这年头还不支持 css3 的浏览器可以不管了

比如这几个伪类:
* link 链接还没被用户点击
* visited 已经点击的链接
* hover 鼠标指针悬停在链接上
* active 链接正在被点击（鼠标在元素上按下，还没有释放）

`::first-letter` 给我感觉更像一个增强选择器

```css
p::first-letter {font-size:300%;}
```

`p::first-line {font-variant:small-caps;}` 同上


```css
p.age::before {content:"Age: ";}
p.age::after {content:" years.";}
```
这个已经是改

书上是说都可以，可是chrome对于hover只认`:`，不能用`::`
```css
.round-icon:hover{
    font-size: 17px;
}
```
title: css 伪类

```bash
echo 1 > /proc/sys/net/ipv4/ip_forward
```

规则里看不到，但实际已经生效了

## fedora


```bash
iptables -t nat -I POSTROUTING -p tcp --dport 1521 -j MASQUERADE

service iptables restart
```

content:
创建一个 Swap 文件
```bash
mkdir swap
cd swap
sudo dd if=/dev/zero of=swapfile bs=1024 count=900000
```
把生成的文件转换成 Swap 文件
```bash
sudo mkswap swapfile
```
激活 Swap 文件
```
sudo swapon swapfile
```

增加我不知道怎么弄, 只会先删除了,再加
```bash
sudo swapoff swapfile
rm -rf swapfile
sudo dd if=/dev/zero of=swapfile bs=1024 count=1200000
sudo mkswap swapfile
sudo swapon swapfile
```
title: ubuntu 增加 swap

content:
## 导出
### 参数介绍
用 pg_dump 就可以, pg_dump后面跟要导出的数据库
- -U 指定用户
- -f 指定导入哪个文件
- -t 指定只导出哪个表
- -h 从哪个服务器导出
- --password 说明需要输入密码
- -s 只导出表结构就加上这个

### 例子
#### 只导出表结构
`-s` 参数用来控制是否只导出表结构
```bash
pg_dump -s -h 135.33.2.36 monitor -U monitor --password -f monitor_struct.dump
```
### 远程导出
```bash
pg_dump db -U db -f db.sql -h 42.96.204.146 --password
```
#### 本地导出
本地导出就不用加上 h
```bash
pg_dump -s  hold -U hold --password -f hold.dump
```
#### 指定端口导出
需要指定端口就加上 p
```bash
pg_dump -s  -h highwe.net -p 5433 hold -U hold --password -f hold_c.dump
```
#### 指定表导出
* 查出哪些表要导 
```bash
select '-t '||tablename from pg_tables where tableowner='monitor' and tablename not like 'log%' and tablename not like 'his%'
```
加上 t 来导出即可
```bash
pg_dump monitor -U monitor -t all_tuxedo_mon -t tuxedo_mon -t vc_file -t bsn_tmp -t host_info -t webservice -t webservice_detail_mon -t sys_user -t sys -t client -t bss_org -t vc_detail -t user_info -t sys_log -t client_not_need -t process_index -t vc_feecard -t client_bak -t pid_mon_20130303 -t file_mon_20130303 -t process_mon -t process -t all_process_mon -t pid_mon_bak_20130321 -t threshold -t user_mon_bak_2013_05 -t warning_relation -t client_20130530 -t vc_monitor -t itsm_modify_mon -t base_mon -t client_20130513 -t all_cpu_mon -t cpu_mon -t mem_mon -t all_mem_mon -t sr_net_mon -t all_sr_net_mon -t all_disk_mon -t disk_mon -t all_oracle_mon -t oracle_mon -t sr_net_mon_bak -t all_tablespace_mon -t tablespace_mon -t tbs_mon -t all_pid_mon -t pid_mon -t all_warning -t all_file_mon -t warning -t file_mon -t removed_warning -t all_user_mon -t user_mon -t all_net_mon -t net_mon -t all_oracle_user_mon -t oracle_user_mon -f monitor.sql.20130604
```
* -T 指定不导出 
```bash
pg_dump hold -U hold -T his* --password -f hold.sql
```
## 导入
用 psql 就可以了, 本机不用指定密码
- -d 指定数据库
- -U 指定用户
- -f 指定导出的文件
- -h 指定服务器
- --password 说明需要输入密码

本机
```bash
psql -d yemai -U yemai -f yemai.dump
```
远程
```bash
psql -h 135.33.2.36 -d monitor -U monitor --password -f tmp.dump
```
也可以用
```bash
#psql datebasename < data.sql
```


### 远程
```bash
pg_dump -h 135.33.2.36 monitor -U monitor -p 5432 --password  -f monitor.sql
pg_dump -h djoin.net redmine -U redmine -p 5432 --password  -f redmine.sql
pg_dump -h portal-bigzhu.dotcloud.com template1 -U root -p 14458 --password  -f database.sql

pg_dump -h 135.32.9.99 itsm -U postgres -p 5432 --password  -f itsm.sql



pg_dump -h djoin.net monitor -U monitor -f monitor.dump

pg_dump -t base_mon -h djoin.net monitor -U monitor --password -f tmp.dump
pg_dump -t base_mon -h 135.33.2.36 monitor -U monitor --password -f tmp.dump

pg_dump -h 135.32.9.98 -T 'all_app_mon*' -T 'removed_warning' -T '*bak*' -T '*his*' -T 'his*' -T 'log*'  monitor -U monitor -F c -b -v -f "./monitor_db_20140411.bak"
```

## 导入数据库
```bash
psql -h 135.33.2.36 -d monitor -U monitor -f tmp.dump

psql -d monitor -f monitor.sql
psql portal -U bigzhu --password -f portal.sql
psql -d bigzhu -f bigzhu.sql
psql -d monitor -f monitor.sql

psql -d monitor -h djoin.net -U monitor -f client.sql
psql -d monitor -h djoin.net -U monitor -f sys
```
也可以用
#psql datebasename < data.sql
## 其他
* [postgresql 二进制导入导出](postgresql 二进制导入导出.md)
* [postgresql 不导出某些表](postgresql 不导出某些表.md)
title: postgresql 导入导出 pg_dump

content:
主要是用`-T`这个参数, 可以多次使用，也可以用通配符
```bash
PGPASSWORD="mypass" pg_dump -T 'his*' -T 'log*' -T 'vc_detail' -i -h localhost -p 5432 -U username -F c -b -v -f dumpfilename.dump databasename
```
title: postgresql 不导出某些表

用在非人工参与的时候，比如用sh来自动备份数据库

```bash
PGPASSWORD="mypass" pg_dump -i -h localhost -p 5432 -U username -F c -b -v -f dumpfilename.dump databasename
```

content:
javascript果然是很烂

要从list里删一个元素，python再简单不过了，可是javascript简直冏

```js
> myArray = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']
  ["a", "b", "c", "d"]
> delete myArray![pic](0)
  true
> myArray
  [undefined, "b", "c", "d"]
```

要这样
```js
> myArray = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']
  ["a", "b", "c", "d"]
> myArray.splice(0, 2)
  ["a", "b"]
> myArray
  ["c", "d"]
```

我要删第一个元素得这样`myArray.splice(0, 1)`
```bash
> myArray = ['a', 'b', 'c', 'd']
  ["a", "b", "c", "d"]
> myArray.splice(0, 1)
  ["a", "b"]
> myArray
  ["c", "d"]
```
title: javascript从list中移除一个元素

content:
## 资金使用方式
据说在新西兰用现金很奇怪:`在使用现金的过程中，会看见很多诧异的目光，只是诧异，但绝对不是鄙视！可能是在新西兰使用现金的人群真的很少吧！我就在路边的冰淇淋店里面买个5元钱的冰淇淋都是可以刷卡的！ `

这里有说明: http://www.kannz.com/use-unionpay-visa-mastercard-in-new-zealand/

总结下来就是，信用卡用起来很方便，基本很多地方都有，但是并不划算, 信用卡的人民币->美元->纽币的方式汇率很高,另外不少新西兰的小商家虽说接受信用卡，但是会针对信用卡的持卡人消费加收2-3%不等的Surcharge，也就是额外收费，因为做生意不容易啊，利润率太低，如果顾客再刷信用卡那就快赔本啦

现金用起来可能商家会奇怪，钱可能也不太好找开，但是划算啊。所以还是在国内换好钱，带过去用，虽然看起来土鳖了一些。安全上么，肯定要危险一些，但是应该不至于会被打劫吧。

* 500MB data
* 100 minutes to NZ numbers included with Add-On purchase
* Unlimited TXTs to standard NZ numbers
* $2 for 60 minutes International calling to our top 30 countries
* Add an extra 500MB for $12

公寓電話亭wifi, 只要是spark用戶每天有會有1G的free上網

19*2*4 =  152 元 1g 的流量 12天，应该也够了, 出去玩就不要每天抱着手机上网了。

== 插头 == 
新西兰的插头与国内的三角插头一样，国内的拿过去就可以用

content:
以前用过 oracle 的物化视图，是用来导数据

现在我有一个很大的多表union select，普通的view没法用上索引，还要全表扫，太慢了，得上这个。
```sql
CREATE MATERIALIZED VIEW mymatview AS SELECT * FROM mytab;
```
执行
```sql
REFRESH MATERIALIZED VIEW  M-View的名稱
```
会把数据刷过去

普通view查询耗时
```
2015-08-17 22:25:30.744101
2015-08-17 22:25:31.460373
```
MATERIALIZED VIEW 耗时
```
2015-08-17 22:26:41.399993
2015-08-17 22:26:41.471737
```
1.3s秒和0.1s的区别，差异相当大

随着数据量增大，差异还会继续扩大
link: 使用postgresql的物化视图materialized view来加速查询.html

content:
## 核心基础功能
* 用户权限相关
* 消息交互
* 调用手机多媒体设备(拍照,录音,视频)
* 获取手机地理位置
* 获取手机摇一摇
* js接口
## 附加功能
* 微信小店
* 微信卡券
* 微信门店
* 语义理解
* 设备功能(连接其他智能设备)
* wifi管理(与门店结合)
 
在基础功能上, 能做的的应用功能是没有限制的, 只要是网站能做的功能都可以整合
## 摄影大赛使用到的微信功能
* 基础的调用凭证相关控制
* 调用微信拍照功能, 与本系统整合
* 上传多媒体文件, 存储到本系统
* 用户基础信息获取
* 与微信用户信息交互能力
    * 发送文本消息 
    * 发送图片消息
    * 发送语音消息
    * 发送视频消息
    * 发送音乐消息
    * 发送图文消息
* js接口, 精确控制验证用户对特定网页的访问权限

## 其他使用过的能力
* 生成带特定信息的二维码, 扫描后与系统本身用户绑定
## 总结
目前很难总结出基于微信我们做的基于微信, 成体系的可以给销售直接拿去给用户推销的东西

yemai 可以整合微信做推荐通知, hold 更可以整合做监控通知.

tower 目前也利用了微信的消息通知, 同时直接引导用户进到他的网站, 省去用户输入网圵和登录的麻烦

所以也只能以应用系统本身的业务需求出发, 再来想利用微信移动端的能力可以结合做什么.

content:
github 只允许 50M 的头件大小


不要以为简单删除了可以了, github会将其留在历史里面

用这个长命令可以删除,但是很慢
```bash
git filter-branch --force --index-filter 'git rm --cached --ignore-unmatch safe.sql' --prune-empty --tag-name-filter cat -- --all
git filter-branch --force --index-filter 'git rm --cached --ignore-unmatch old.sql' --prune-empty --tag-name-filter cat -- --all
```

比较好的办法是用bfg:https://rtyley.github.io/bfg-repo-cleaner/

下载了 bfg.jar 以后,可以:
 

删除指定的文件:`java -jar ~/Downloads/bfg-1.12.3.jar --delete-files old.sql`

删除大于多少的文件: `java -jar ~/Downloads/bfg-1.12.3.jar --strip-blobs-bigger-than 50M`

```python
def get_content_type(self):
...
```

```python
Python 2.7.10 (default, May 27 2015, 18:11:38)

Type "help", "copyright", "credits" or "license" for more information.
```

content:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/21248222/how-can-tornado-serve-a-single-static-file-at-an-arbitrary-location
```python
app = tornado.web.Application([
(r'/foo.json()', tornado.web.StaticFileHandler, {'path': '/path/to/foo.json'})
])
```
StaticFileHandler expects two arguments, so if you want a single url (/foo.json) to be mapped to your file path you can use:


The regex will match /foo.json and send the empty capture group (), which will cause the filepath to be used as is. When the capture group is not empty, /path/to/foo.json will be treated as a directory /path/to/foo.json/, and the handler will try to match whatever is within the capture group to a file name in that directory.


通过加上一个`()`来解决问题, 优雅~

content:
我的网站收到了 /robots.txt 的请求, 找了一下, 发现了说明:

https://zh.wikipedia.org/wiki/Robots.txt

robots.txt（统一小写）是一种存放于网站根目录下的ASCII编码的文本文件，它通常告诉网络搜索引擎的漫游器（又称网络蜘蛛），此网站中的哪些内容是不应被搜索引擎的漫游器获取的，哪些是可以被漫游器获取的。因为一些系统中的URL是大小写敏感的，所以robots.txt的文件名应统一为小写。robots.txt应放置于网站的根目录下。如果想单独定义搜索引擎的漫游器访问子目录时的行为，那么可以将自定的设置合并到根目录下的robots.txt，或者使用robots元数据（Metadata，又称元数据）。


还可以把 [sitemap](sitemap.md) 放到这里面来
title: robots.txt

动态网站的使用要用到代理
```bash
browser-sync start --proxy "127.0.0.1:9000" --files "*.css"
```

`127.0.0.1:9000`是原本的server的地址

BrowserSync 会给你一个新的地址

要监听所有文件可以这样


从twitter取到的时间, 插入数据库,差了8小时

http://www.reddit.com/r/learnpython/comments/198whr/tweepy_datetime_issue/

第一种方式,用pytz
```python
import pytz
tz = pytz.timezone('Asia/Shanghai')
tweet.created_at = tz.localize(tweet.created_at)
tweet.created_at += timedelta(hours=8)
print tweet.created_at
```
打出来,比原来多了一个+8在后面, 可是insert数据库后,还是差了8

只有手工来弄
```python
from datetime import timedelta
tweet.created_at += timedelta(hours=8)
```
粗暴简单, 但是有用

content:
普通的使用是这样的
```python
import requests
requests.get('https://api.github.com//users/bigzhu/events')
r.json()
```

首先要取到etag
```python
import requests
r = requests.get('https://api.github.com/users/bigzhu/events')
print r.headers![pic]('etag')
```
取了一次数以后,把这个etag存留下来

下次把etag送过去,如果数据没变,就不会有数据过来了
```bash
import requests
headers = {'If-None-Match': 'W/"a6c901716f63cce455c57592577abff4"'}
r = requests.get('https://api.github.com/users/bigzhu/events', headers=headers)
print r.status_code
```
返回的 status_code 是 304, 数据也不再会送过来了
